title: enjoyed
review: We enjoyed walking around the Ashram for about an hour or so  It is an interesting experience  seeing the abandoned buildings and the new paintings.  A girl from Australia was doing a painting while we were there.  It is a nice park where you can wander around without crowds.

title: A must see if you’re interested in The Beatles or history of popular culture
review: About 45mins walk from LaxmanJhula Bridge is the former ashram of Maharishi Mahesh yogi (founder of Transcendental Meditation “TM” movement). This is where the Beatles famously stayed in the late 60s and wrote a lot of material. Despite its previous place in the limelight the ashram is now a series of ruins and crumbling buildings but it’s still fascinating to wander round, imagine the once buzzing community and admire the well placed graffiti. A must see in Rishikesh, even with the steep 600rs foreigner entrance fee!

title: Peace
review: If you're looking for a respite from the crowd and to find the remains of what Beatles once had and shared , this place is a must visit. The Grafitti on the walls speaks of the times they've had And there is so much peace all around. Look closely and in one of the meditation caves you're likely to find some vagabond painting his/her heart out onto these walls that once stood witness to the art of spirituality and Beatles.

title: Return visit after 10 years
review: Disappointed that the buildings have been vandalised.

title: A must!
review: Now this is something you have to visit. It's an abandonded ashram but full of calm and deep energy. Foreigners pay an entrance fee of 600 rupees, and walking around the whole land will take up to 1,5-2 hours. Go in the afternoon when the light is smooth and you can take amazing photos for your Instagram. There's a small cafeteria, but the thing is just to walk around in empty buildings, look at the artwork on the walls and just let Maharishi Mahesh Yogi ashrams energy to sink in. And very near is the tree where Papaji (Mooji's master) used to give satsang when he was in Rishikesh. It is the biggest tree just outside the entrance, ask the staff if you don't find it.

title: Beatles Ashram
review: Not quite whats everyone expects. The place is run down and unkept. Spend about 30 minutes visiting the place. Give it a miss, you would not miss much!

title: Little gem
review: Found by chance , beetles retreat, neglected , but still worth a walk around . Takes about an hour , cost 600 r . Not much information about he place , which is a shame . The photos are good . But only been done later . Been there , which is a possative, but wouldn't go back . Only coz I'm a beetles fan .

title: Brilliant
review: Really enjoyed the peace and beauty of this place, fascinating to walk round all the buildings even though they are left to the wild to take over, a leopard was spotted from one of the buildings. Artwork worth seeing, Cafe on site where you can get refreshments and small snacks, we could of spent the whole day there, would highly recommend

title: Nice place to relax
review: It is a very calming atmosphere and a quiet getaway. I loved the nature around it and the abandoned places.

title: Great Place - wonderful relaxing atmosphere
review: I walked there and back. It takes about 40min each way from Laxmanjhula Bridge.

title: Money minting for forest department
review: The Beatles Ashram could be a major tourism  landmark for Rishikesh. The footfall is increasing but the forest department is not the competent agency to develop this unique place. It needs a solid plan,

title: More than just The Beatles
review: I didn't know what to expect but because I am a great Beatles fan I had to visit. From the outside it doesnt look like much but it is definitely worth the entrance fee. The ruins, the art, the history that runs trough this place.. its amazing. Take a couple of hours, and just roam freely and discover the whole place. Lots of small secrets to be found.c

title: Worth a visit
review: 600 rupees entrance fee is overpriced but worth visiting still. Easy to find not sure how you can get lost it’s one straight road. Great graffiti art

title: Going back in time
review: After driving for more than one hour on barrage road from Haridwar, I reached this Aashram... They have entry fee of 150 for indian adult, Rs 600 for foreigners Rs 75 for seniors . I was with my American friend. For once l thought I made mistake by coming to this place...I went towards banks of Ganges, thought for a while and than entered ruins of this ashram... My walk around looking at meditation caves, graffiti and other ruins took me to past ...

title: Nice perspective on Mahesh Yogi and the TM movement
review: Part of history, nice and simple depiction of Mahesh Yogi's once bustling ashram, from where Indian spirituality caught the world's attention and spread through. Once can spend some peaceful time here.

title: Like common down from a sugar rush
review: All hyped up by the fame of the band. What I witnessed was sad degradation and neglect of sturdy structures in a country with so many homeless...... For 600 rupees, no thank you. Only highlight was the photography display of the Beatles visit.

title: A must-see when in Rishikesh
review: What a wonderful way to spend several hours in this beautiful, deserted Ashram. The art work that adorns many of the walls is astounding, and seems to be growing every year, and it's quite mesmerising to see Mother Nature reclaiming her position.

title: Great if you do it for the 'gram
review: Amazing place, beautiful scenery and incredible graffiti. I wasn't expecting a lot but it was very interesting and we had gorgeous photos. Close to Rajaji National Park - go on safari to see the elephants early in the morning.

title: Loved this!
review: Highly recommend a visit here! Worth a few hours. Bring a journal, something to sit on, and maybe your mala beads if that's your thing!

title: Disappointed with high entrance fee
review: The way that the authorities capitalize on this ancient spiritual site appears very disrespectful to its original creator. Reopened only recently to earn profit from the influx of Westerners, and imposing a ridiculously high entrance fee only for foreigners, this fact totaly put us off exploring these mystic, "bee hive" - like structures, close to the jungle. Maharishi Mahesh Yogi wouldnt be happy with the commercial metamorphosis of his sanctuary, rather known as "The Beatles Ashram". Very disappointing.

title: Total waste of time and money
review: As a huge Beatles fan this was one of the pilgrimage sites that I wanted to visit.

title: Charming abandoned ashram with great artworks but expensive entry fee
review: The place is a group of abandoned buildings decorated with nice artworks. There is a small exhibition, like 3 rooms with pictures of the ashram’s past. There is a cafe right next to it. We liked the place as it had really good vibes and it was real nice to spend a few hours in quite which is rare in Rishikesh. We enjoyed the view from the top and did some yoga and meditation there. I would recommend the place if you are prepared to pay the 600 rupe entry fee, which seems very high compared to something like the Taj Mahal where the entry fee is 1100.

title: Really cool ashram
review: We walked here from our hotel and shopped along the way. It is 600inr to enter, which i think is being used to restore this place to its former glory. It is much bigger than i thought. I was hoping for more Beatles graffiti art, but it looks like most had been removed. The ashrams made out of stone are worth seeing. Super cool. I can see how the Beatles would have wanted to escape to this place. Lots of monkeys outside the enterance. Don't feed them! They will stay a proper distance.

title: Beatles Ashram
review: Ticket prices are bit too high.. Beatles Ashram is one of the good places to wander, Its little away from the noise of town which is good. I like the nature around however it needed to be maintained and clean.

title: Beatles ashram.
review: This place is away form all the noise of the town.

title: Imagine...
review: It was strange to visit the Beatles' Ashram in Ram Jhula, Rishikesh, for their 50 years arrival in India, in fact Maharishi Mahesh Yogi's Ashram of Transcendental Meditation. 600 Indian Rs for foreigners' entry fee, it's a lot for ruins of TM headquarters, but the meditation with International Yoga Festival 2018 Sangha of Parmarth Niketan Ashram brought Love Life Light Laughter to what appears a dead place, except for the artists' paintings and graffitis all over. Great also to have sung John Lennon's 'Imagine' with beloved Bhakti singer Daphne Tse in company of all Yogis & Yoginis present from over 100 countries around Pujya Swami Chidanand Sarasvati ji. Let it be!

title: Worth a visit
review: In the hectic environment of my first visit to India ... with constant horns blowing, people and building everywhere... this was a wonderful oasis of calm!  The only reason I did not give it five stars is that I would have loved it more had it been a working ashram... where I could have stayed and practiced yoga, meditation and the simple living that it promoted in the 1960’s.

title: History with sadness
review: I always wanted to visit the famous ashram where Beatles met with Indian culture and studied under the famed Mahareshi Mahesh Yogi, in the 60’s. While I fulfilled my bucket wish list item, I was saddened by the deteriorating condition of complex built by the “father” of Transcendental Meditation, Mahareshi Mahesh Yogi, in the sixties. Furthermore, the experience was, somewhat, marred by the knowledge of conduct of the Yogi with some of his female students, which caused a rift between him and two of the Beatles and resulted in their departure from the ashram.

title: Derelict yet Peaceful
review: This Ashram is clearly a gem. Even though it’s clearly overgrown and claimed by the forest, the vibe is very peaceful. For Beatles lovers, a little museum and the graffiti is a great way to capture the vibe of those times

title: A musical fans must
review: This Ashram has a museum of pics and info of The Beatles time spent here in the 70’s. Each area of the now dilapidated ashram has a board with info on each area eg Communal dining hall, residence and kitchen.

title: Make sure you reach before time
review: They shut at 4 PM. And are very strict about entry post that. Make sure you reach early to gain access.

title: Interesting
review: The walk to the ashram and the Rajjaji National Park was excellent. They are charging entry fee Rs.150 so unless you are desperate to go in avoid. The walk to and around the area and the Ganga beach near Gita Bhavan is wonderful quiet.

title: Lost
review: Couldn’t find how to get in. Very poorly signposted. I think the gate is on the riverside. It’s not where google maps will send you for Beatles Ashram.

title: Better than expected!
review: This must've been absolutely beautiful when it was opened and in use. Now although abandoned, you can still appreciate it and enjoy a nice walk through the retreat center. It was better and bigger than expected. Definitely a must! It has an area with great views of Ganga River and Rishikesh.

title: Very nice to have been here
review: A bit run down unfortunately, but a nice 45 min walk from Rishikesh, well worth it to spend one afternoon here.

title: Fantastic!
review: Better and bigger than expected! And although abandoned, you can enjoy a nice stroll through time and picture it how once was. There are also nice views of Rishikesh from up there.

title: A not to miss attraction in RIshikesh!
review: I've been to the Beatles ashram 3 times already and am going to go back again.  It's a photographer's paradise and the energy feels so good here.  I recommend going early in the day as it's a bit out of town and you'll want to stay all day!  So worth the 600 rupee admission fee!

title: A place of peace, interesting ruins, broken dreams and artwork.
review: My hubby and I loved our visit to the Ashram. Yes its dilapidated and ruined and nature has reclaimed her ground, but we spent a fascinating and leisurely tour by ourselves here. It was nice to get away from the bustle and traffic of Rishikesh and hear the sounds of nature and bird song for a while. Also loved the graffitti art throughout the various buildings. We could only imagine what a heavenly utopia this place would have been in its heyday. We went when it opened at around 10am and were the first ones there. Please note closing time (4pm?) as its a fair walk from the Rishikesh bridges only to be turned back. This is an awesome place of peace, interesting ruins, broken dreams, artwork and some great photography opps! I sang Beatles tunes all the way through!

title: Its one of the famous sites to be visited in rishikeash...!
review: t’s quite a walk to the ashram, one would get surprised the entry does not mention of Beatles ashram, there they mention Rajaji Tiger Reserve which spans behind the Ashram having around 2 male and three female tigers. The ashram is in ruins, the government has taken up some restoration work under the name of “The Beatles Ashram”, we could see a small café and a photo exhibit of the Beatles stay in the Ashram. The whole ashram was all designed by Maharishi, which houses over around 100 buildings. Its real trip down the memory lane, worth the time spent. The place is quite a huge one can see post office also among the ruins  ….! God is strange in his ways

title: Worth seeing!!
review: If you are a Beatles fan this is a must visit and if you are not it is a must visit.  I had no idea how much this place influenced their music.  Have a guide take you who knows the history..if not go to the museum part first

title: Wow!
review: Be open and willing to see the things that are there as you walk through the experience.  We  were wowed by some of the facilities and then came upon 40 Italians singing Yellow Submarine and other Beatles greats.

title: Interesting trivia for Beatles' fans
review: The erstwhile Beatles Ashram by the holy Ganga in Rishkesh lies in ruins and is now a Tiger Reserve, but enough remains of the original sprawling campus to excite fans of the hugely popular pop group of the '60s and '70s. The picture gallery and vestiges of buildings give clear evidence of the daily life of it's large community of dwellers.

title: Magical
review: If like me, you are very intuitive to energy around you, then i ded suggest spending a late afternoon at the.ashram.

title: Nice - Worth a visit
review: Chaurasi Kutiya (84) - famous for many reasons, one being for Meditation. Some years back, people used to come and stay in these kutiyas to Meditate. Another reason which drew attention to this place was that when the world famous band called "Beatles" came to India, they were so inspired by this place that they decide to run it for some time. Now this place is taken care of by the Government. This place had hundreds of Small Doom styled two-story structure, where many people came and practised Meditation, though this place was now in ruins, still it had its own Old World charm.

title: Fabulous tour of the Beatles Ashram
review: We were fortunate to have Raja Richard, a devotee of Maharishi mahesh yogi give us a personal tour of this fascinating Ashram. Richard is working with the government to help restore this amazing and historic Ashram, the first Ashram in what is now the Ashram and spiritual capital of India. I definitely recommend visiting the Ashram and if possible having a tour with a knowledgeable person.

title: Beatles Ashram trip
review: An amazing mini city in the middle if forest perfect in construction and amenities. A marvel of 60s and 70s and a must visit place.

title: Amazing indian
review: India is one of the most Colourful country ,rich in history, culture, foods and art and more..... not only incredible, amazing, magical. If you have enough patience to see you will find te Jewels in this part of world. Namaste.

title: Top Site to Visit in Rishikesh
review: For the millions of people around the world who are practicing Maharishi's Transcendental Meditation technique, and for all Beatles fans, this is the real thing! Built on leased government land in the 1960's, the forestry department has finally shown some interest in the abandoned site. Maharishi left in the 70's and the forest reclaimed the property. Now the place is being reborn as: The Beatles Ashram. Lovely setting above the Ganga, the buildings are under repair, the property is fenced and protected, and it's being fixed up. There is already a nice Beatles photo exhibit in one of the repaired buildings.

title: Ashram
review: This is the ashram which the legendary Beatles had visited way back. Now it is closed and no longer in use.

title: Over priced however worth a visit
review: 600inr to enter a ruin pretty much. Not sure where that money goes as it is all overgrown and abandoned. This does give it a more spiritual feel to it I guess though and is worth a walk round. It isn't signposted but not hard to find if you follow the road it's right at the end.

title: A Walk Through art & history
review: Originally beatles ashram was known as Maharishi Mahesh Yogi Ashram located in a beautiful spot with in Raja Ji National Park with holy river ganges flowing quietly behind it.

title: Interesting spot worth the venturing
review: This place is definitely not touristy. I had to find the ticketing counter on my own to enter the Ashram. Go early enough and find yourself ALONE in this big space. I don't deny that it felt really eerie at first - esp if you're like me and would walk into the dark spaces and structures on your own. I would say it's really safe though. And climb up to the wall-less structure to the top for an amazing feeling top-down.

title: Is it worth 600rp?
review: The good ol' Beatles Ashram is an old, run down derelict building that hasn't received much attention or l care for decades.

title: What a sham
review: My wife and her friend really wanted to go so we went, but it’s crazy coz for foreigners it’s 600Rupees and for Indians native or foreign born it’s 150 rs!!!

title: Great vibe
review: Off the beaten track now and more of an archeological sure but still very special and worth the visit

title: Dirty
review: Nice graffiti

title: Unique place in Rishikesh
review: I have been a frequent traveller to rishikesh from last few years but this was the first time that I visited this place and found this place quite unique and this adds another flavor to the beauty of rishkesh..the artwork done by the artists are at par.

title: 5 reasons to visit the Beatles ashram
review: Actually I was doubting to go, after reading the different reviews. Also because they charge tourists 4 times more. But I am happy that I went. Firstly the located is at a beautiful place, a really peaceful area. Secondly it is really huge, much bigger then I had expected before. You can easily spend there hours. Thirdly, there are beautiful paintings. So if you like art then it is a must visit. Fifthly the bad maintenance makes it even more beautiful. The nature is slowly taking over the buildings.

title: Truly wonderful place!
review: This place is off the beaten track, and we were taken there by our wonderful driver.  The ashram is run down as you would expect but is a fantastic place to explore.A lovely photo exhibition gives a feel of the place in the 60's.  Many photo opportunities and worth a walk all the way to the top for the view of the Ganges and Rishikesh - stunning.  Amazing as an archelogical site - wonder if they will ever restore into a working Ashram - it would be completely worth it.  Beautiful artwork throughout.

title: Nostalgic
review: It is Maharishi Mahesh Yogi’s Ashram which now lies abandoned. Beatles apparently spent a year here. The new name is probably just to attract foreign tourists. It is part of a natural tiger reserve. The route is not signposted and can be easily missed.

title: The place
review: i visit beatles ashrm when . i like it beatles visit for meditation it very good maintained huts are veyr nice.

title: A creepy and offbeat location
review: Its an old abandoned ashram, and is full of dilapidated buildings. Its like you are visiting a haunted movie set, you see old half-broken buildings everywhere, surrounded by large trees. The walls are full of varied graffiti both beautiful and outrageous. Its located in the rajaji national park so you have to LEAVE by 5:30pm, so plan accordingly.

title: Serenity lingers on at this paradise
review: I loved my sweet cup of ginger lemon honey tea, my staple drink in the hills, served with a smile at the restaurant. The setting is idyllic and inspires one to soak in the natural calm and peace. Order anything, as long as you get a chance to me the cuddly tomcat. Vegetarian fare, like everywhere else in Rishikesh. Delightful!

title: Step back in the time of the beatle.
review: It was quite far from where we was staying (@ the Laxman Jhula Bridge). It's best to hire a ride to get you there because you'll be walking around seeing the buildings/area.  The location and religious vibe helped shape the Beatles mind and help their creative juices. Make sure you make it further back in the compound to see the 4 or 5 story building that housed many who stayed there during the Beatles time. There are quite a few and humorous graffiti on most if no all the walls of the building. Definitely one of the most enjoyable places we visited while in Rishikesh.

title: Its a joke in the name of Beatles
review: I was not expecting something out of this world from this Ashram. We know that Beatles stayed here in the 60s and this place might have given them the inspiration to write some of their hits, but the way this place is maintained is quite poor.

title: A place to re discover one!!
review: Had a chance to work with great artist pan, Rachel and tushar to renovate the art at the beatles for the re opening of this place and to discover hidden secrets of this place through Maharishi Mahesh Yogi grandson.

title: Fun journey
review: Its situated in the Rajaji park in Rishikesh

title: A feeling of belonging
review: Being a Transcendental Meditation practitioner, visiting the Ashram gave me a source of belonging, all the time I was vising I couldn't believe that I was really there. The energy in the place is amazing, the meditation caves are so beautiful.  I wished I had the chance back then to be with "Maharshi Mahesh Yogi" in the Ashram, imagine how lucky I would have been.

title: An interesting trip back in time
review: A walk through Rishikesh will bring you to the Beatles Ashram - so strange to see all of the run down buildings and ruins from the 60's when this was a thriving location. There are murals everywhere and a photo gallery of their time at the Ashram. They wrote most of the White Album here. Worth a look if you are a Beatles fan! PS - our guide took us here - we would never have found it!

title: Check out the Amazing Murals!!
review: The Beetles Ashram today is an abandoned structure at the extreme end of the Swarg Ashram area - about a kilometer's easy walk from Parmarth Niketan or Vanaprasth Ashram. Other than the fact that you are walking around the place where the Beetle came for solace - to participate in advanced Transcendental Meditation under Maharishi Mahesh Yogi in February 1968,[riddled with it's own controversies] this place has only the Murals - Artxpan - that blew my mind.

title: Not a Beatles fan but still loved it
review: The vibe of the place along with the artwork…simply amazing. Foreigners have to pay 600 rupees but totally worth it.

title: A Travel In Time
review: Rishikesh became famous on the Global Travel map almost 50 yrs back, when the Beatles came down here in search of their "enlightenment"

title: Place of peace
review: Being a Beatles fan, this place is steeped in history. Must see place for every Beatles fan to understand where they found their inner peace and fulfilment which lead John Lennon & co to make great music inspired by Love, peace and tranquility

title: 600rupee to time travel
review: We were in Rishikesh during the Kanwa Yatra festival. Thousands of people flocked into this city to participate in such a big religious experience.

title: Great place to visit!!!!!!!
review: The Beatles visited this Ashram 50 years ago it is great to walk around the abandoned compound trying to imagine what their experience was like. The meditation caves are fascinating and just imagining what it took to get from Delhi to Rishikesh half a century ago is amazing.

title: love it
review: i visit beatles ashrm when i come to ram jhula walking too much so take car. i like it beatles visit for meditation it very good maintained huts are ver nice. I click beautiful photo of this place but entry very costly

title: A very unique place
review: I'm not a big Beatles fan, but enjoyed my visit to this Ashram. Liked the meditation huts, scenic surroundings.

title: Wonderful Place in the early hours of the day
review: We went there quiet early in the morning and one can surely experience how this place inspired the four beatles.A must see place for a musician and even you can feel the strong essense of blissfulness getting out of the surrounding.

title: The Beatles Ashram
review: Since the Beatles set foot in Rishikesh in the late 60's , this place has been a tourist attraction for anyone who is interested in Yoga and meditation. Impressed by the teachings of Maharishi Mahesh Yogi the Beatles flew down to Rishikesh and stayed at his ashram which is now famously known as the 'Beatles Ashram'. One can take a look at the eye - catching graffiti and paintings done by the visitors on the wall of the abandoned ashram.

title: Young kids would luv this place
review: Chaurasikutiya aka Beatlesashram Rishikesh is a spectacular wonder to explore. Beatles came here in 1968 to learn transcendental meditation (TM) from Maharishi Mahesh Yogi. During there stay here they wrote many famous songs.

title: So Peace full Place
review: A really wonderful place lost inside the chaotic Indian atmosphere opposite of the main town of Rishikesh. The Beatles history is not thoroughly put up so you have to go about that with your own love for Beatles. The artworks contributed by the people who've followed the name till here is very wonderful and amazing. The people meditating, the sounds of birds and insects and the monkeys out here plus the old ruins make it a pleasurable place. Please don't litter this place as it's already low on maintenance and just simply Let It Be.

title: Good trip
review: It's good to visit for some time with friends as it is something one might not expect in Rishikesh...

title: Very different,excellent
review: The ambience was great. It’s a must go place if you visit Rishikesh. Excellent hospitality. It’s very popular with foreign tourists. Cafe is very nice.

title: NOT WORTH IT- crazy expensive!
review: We thought about going by, taking it easy.. Have a walk, taking few pics

title: Great for Beatles Fans, and for quiet seekers
review: I enjoyed my little sojourn of the so-called Beatles Ashram, which is actuallythe Chaurasi Kutiya Ashram. This was the ashram of the controversial Mahesh Yogi. But it came to limelight due to brief but eventful trip by the 4 members of Beatles in 1968. The ashram today is in much dilapidated condition. I think this must have been restored and given a retro looks. There are some 84 meditation pods here so it is called Chaurasi Kutiya. For me Rs. 150 entry fees is not so much but i also think that Rs. 600 entry fees for foreigners is rather steep.

title: 600 Entry Fee for Foreigners, Rs 150 For Indians!
review: Beatles Ashram was a major attraction for foreigners and it was free. Where they created very nice Graffiti, painting around the Beatles Ashram. Now Indian government took over this place and cashing out :)

title: Epic
review: If you can get past the exorbitant entrance fee to the park it is worth it. The abandoned ashram is eerily beautiful and knowing who walked the grounds in search of transcendence makes it feel powerful. Bring a good camera and read up on your Beatles history before coming to get the most out of the experience. You can also walk from main Rishikesh, it is a leisurely 40minute walk down a treelined market clad road full of chai stands and street food delights.

title: The Best
review: Best Wall paintings with beautiful quotes I have ever seen. Try not going solo because taking selfies really suck.

title: meditation place abandoned
review: we made it there just before 5 pm closing time.. walk in as far as you can, because the art work in deep inside among the abandoned structures.. try enter one of those meditation cells theyre interesting from inside too..

title: Different
review: Heard lot from local people . As i was on business trip so couldnt spend much time . Its purely foriegners hub . Nice cafe

title: Chaurasy Kutian (84 Hutments): A Maharishi's Ashram of Its Time
review: A calm n peaceful place to visit, which is now deserted and in ruins. It was built in 1960s and where Beatles stayed in 1968 to compose their beautiful songs. It was the famous center for TM Siddhi for a long time. It was brought in lime light in 2017 when Beatles were reunited by Mr. Lynch. A worth place to visit, i one is in Rishikesh either for leisure or pilgrimage. It has wall paintings and a museum on Beatles stay here.

title: Fun activity worth the entrance fee
review: Interesting photo exhibition and eerie ruins to explore of this former ashram visited by the Beatles and other 60s icons. Also interesting graffiti. It's worth the 600 rupees foreigner entrance fee - we were almost put off by the price but decided to go for it and it was a fascinating place to see.

title: Amazing place to visit
review: Very authentic experience of what the old ashrams looked like when the Beatles came...very eccentric place..dont miss it :)

title: Adventure trip
review: The Ashram is waste of Money ...Not maintained at all...no drinking water at all and charge is Rs 150/-... exorbitant high.

title: Peaceful ashram
review: This is a quiet and peaceful ashram in Rishikesh, there is a shop for us to get some snacks or drinks. But for foreigners we have to pay some bucks.

title: Very awesome place
review: Is good for couples. Me and my soulmate meet first time here. Its very fabulous place. I like the art. It is still on renovation. I love it . for indian citizen its only 150inr so according to mee its excellent place in Rishikesh for couples. No body with disturb you.

title: Skippable
review: This is just ruins! You'll like it if you like graffiti on walls! Very beautiful graffitis, its a hugeeeee place you'll get tired of all the walking but can be a good place if you're their in winters, but for summers, no!

title: Back in time
review: A step back in time to a different but deeply enlightening way of life. So glad that this beautiful area is being looked after and revived so as we can now see what it was like in the past.

title: fun place
review: imagine beatles meditating in the dark caves here getting enlightened for strawberry fields forever...its a place which closes by 5pm and costs foreigners 600 rupees entry..indians 150 and students 60 rupees

title: It’s an odd place but ok
review: It’s not the most amazing place in the world. In the context of India it’s a lot to go in, 600 rupees.

title: I wish this place goes back to its original purpose
review: I visited the Beatles ashram with a friend during my one month stay in Rishikesh. At the moment it is a tourist attraction and it's left to its own destiny and slow destruction by the forces of mother nature.

title: I finally decided to explore this ashram!!
review: I have get to the door many tiimes for the simple fact that it is located in a nice area, but I had no idea that, by going uphill, I would see the real ashram!! It is so beautiful.... even been abandoned and unexplored. It brings imagination to one´s head by the simple fact of knowing the Beatles have been there!! The meditation chambers are amazing!! The architecture and constructionis of this ashram is surprising. It is pretty much worthwhile to pay 600 Rupees (fee for foreigners) and visit. It is a visit to a recent past that is still alive in our imagination.

title: peaceful history
review: The ashram is run down but amazing to see where the beatles wrote abbey road and the white album. If you are a beatles fan you must visit. I wish I could have seen it in the 60's. Definately worth a visit.

title: A walk through a famous past
review: This is worth an afternoon. From the construction of these meditation caves to the views of the ganges to the photography museum you can imagine why the beatles would fall in love with this special place.

title: A delightful journey through art and history
review: If you have a penchant to explore through history, Beatles Ashram is a must visit. While Beatles band travelled all the way to Rishikesh in 1968 to find peace, little did they know that they would leave behind a piece of their musical vibe here. This ashram is now a  part of the Rajaji National Park. Although this place is now in ruins, in 2015 artists took on a project and left behind sacred murals which are breathtaking for any art lover. Best time to visit is in the morning, they open around 9am.

title: Cool to See
review: It w as amazing to see where the Beatles wrote many of the songs from the White Album, but it was distressing that the buildings were in such bad shape.

title: Surreal experience
review: Having been abondoned since 1984, this place has become overgrown though remains in reasonable condition. It appears that it belongs to the Rajaji National Park now, and they are doing a certain amount of maintenance. I only hope they won't spoil the amazing ambiance of this unique site.

title: Don't go there
review: Pay 600 rp just to see the abandoned ruins, it's ridiculous. There is nothing to see except the graffiti. I'm very disappointed

title: worth the long walk from Rishikesh
review: Nice place to visit if a little rundown, in need of a little more tender care but really nice to see the artwork and the beehive huts, gave way to imagine the beatles composing their songs in the gardens.

title: training course also
review: Duo of yoga calling you once again in Beatles Ashram. ... The Maharishi Mahesh Yogi ashram is located in a beautiful spot within the Rajaji National Park with the river GangaRishikesh in northern India to attend an advanced Transcendental Meditation (TM) training course at the ashram of Maharishi Mahesh Yogi.

title: Fun
review: It's great place if u like nature and ruins... The street type graffities are great for selfies as well.. Beautiful location in rajaji tiger reserve.. The entry fee for the park is bit too much.. But great stone buildings

title: Abandoned but amazing Aashram
review: Visit this place and set aside an entire day for the visit. Keep exploring the prayer halls and the bunglows and find interesting wall paintings.

title: A must
review: If you are in rishikesh u should visit this place, it’s a old ashram were the Beatles stayed and composed a few songs there, it’s a beautiful place with amazings architecture and views, it’s a shame it’s “abandoned” but it’s now kinda of a free art Sanctuary. Worth a visit

title: Great visit beware - Rs.600 for Foreigner
review: Hugely atmospheric abandoned Ashram and TM centre. The decaying buildings have charm and the artwork is great.

title: Rip Off for Foreigners
review: Charing more than 600 from foreigners and almost nothing from indians is no fair and terrible for the things you can see. It's kind of racist, they should threat all tourist the same!!!!

title: Worth a visit
review: We went as part of a group tour and I was not that interested in going but it turned out to be a really great day, it is really interesting and definitely worth a visit we spent a couple of hours there singing Beatles songs in the big hall.

title: Lovely, cultural & spiritual place
review: It’s basically a huge nature reserve with over 100 small stone huts and a few main buildings that are now derelict.

title: Beatles Ashram was amazing
review: Amazing place to visit. Definitely recommend it. Great scenery, fantastic artwork and views. You will certainly enjoy yourself.

title: Highly over priced but still kind of cool.
review: It was over priced because the ashram itself is located within a tiger reserve. We enjoyed walking around and photographing the grafitti, but it wasn't really worth the price or the walk out there.

title: Awesome place
review: Calm & quite place. It's perfectly blended with natural beauty and 84 abandon kuthis. Spirituality in the air. Lots of beautiful murals have painted in the awesome place

title: Calm place for exploring
review: Nice and calm place to relax and have interesting walk for Ashram exploring. However in my opinion, the entrance fee 600 inr is too much because the place is quite abandoned. There are some nice paintings on the walls which you can find inside and outside of the buildings. It was interesting to visit the famous place where the Beatles were to learn transcendental meditation.

title: Fascinating history
review: The location where the white album

title: Its worth a visit if your in Rishikesh already but its in poor delapidated state
review: Its worth the walk from town if your there from stunning views and its worth the entrance to muse at these odd hive like abodes which were created in 1960s shortly after the second world war and futuristic from this point of view but the place is lacking in spirit of the people who stayed here.

title: Very interesting
review: Went there late afternoon before they closed for the day. Great experience. There were almost no one on the territory of ashram and we got to see everything and take photos without any disturbance.

title: Must Visit PLace
review: Recently ARTEX visited this ashram and done an amazing wall art in the main hall of the ashram. Long time back Beatles band was here so it is named after them otherwise it is also called 64 kutia.

title: Beatles Inspiration Mahrishi Mahesh Yogi
review: It is nice place and it has these small concrete house where you can meditate. It is in midst of jungle. 40 YEARS ago it was the place for the transcendental meditation and it was lively. Now only ruins are there but wonderful place. Calm and quiet. Our Yogi's inspire beatles, steve jobs and many more.

title: Beatle purists must see ....
review: Definitely a stop for serious Beatles fans.  Although the surrounding area is a bit rundown, you may enjoy the artwork and interesting building structures.  Climb to the top of the largest structure for the best overviews.  Foreigner pricing is a bit higher than locals, but, you probably will only be here once ... go for it.  After your visit you can sing one of your favorite Beatles songs on the way out.  Hope this helps with your first visit.

title: Let it be
review: Interesting if you remember the Beatles and their trip to India to study. Read about it before you visit.

title: Pop cultural history
review: Left derelict by the State government but still a piece of cultural history, worth a visit to see where the Beatles lived with the Maharishi

title: Fun piece of pop culture
review: Slowly decaying buildings with some great graffiti and the history of the jet set and the Beatles make it an interesting stop on your itinerary. They even have a cafe for drinks and a photographic exhibition which was interesting.

title: Interesting visit in Rishikesh
review: Abandoned places and buildings have a special magic, but it's sad to see the ashram in such poor conditions. It is worth a visit, though, if you're in Rishikesh. Take some time to appreciate the graffiti as well!

title: Worth it if you love the Beatles!
review: It’s pricey to enter, but it is a beautiful walk around the ashram ruins.

title: Beautiful and Serene Ashram
review: This is a beautiful Ashram located at the top of a hill. It took some time to find it because off the main road there is no clear sign pointing you to the place. It has steep entry charges of Rs. 150 for Indians and Rs. 600 for foreigners. They have strict checking for tickets and fines, so it is advisable to buy tickets from the entry itself.

title: Good view
review: Its worth the visit . Expensive to go in compared with other places (around 600 rúpias) but its a most go.

title: A magical place
review: I loved the Ashram! We visited it early in the morning and where nearly the only ones to explore the ruins. A magical Place and photographers will love it! A must-visit in my opinion :)

title: Super cool
review: I had no idea this was here. I enjoyed my trip.

title: Illegal entrance fee
review: We visited ashram and the fee for foreigners was 600 Rs. At first it is too extreme for seeing ruins. The second - the place belongs to Forest department but the fee is taken by Gauhri Range office. This is not official entrance fee of the Indian government.  The ticket provided is company's recreipt. When we talked about it, we were bullied by the person who collects the fee. Do not recommend anyone to pay illegal entrance.

title: Ruined but graffiti is amazing
review: This place is completely ruined however the ashram's architecture is not to be missed. Located at a distance of about 2 kms from ram jhula, the place is associated with history of Beatles when they came here to practice yoga. The place is not maintained properly but still you will be amazed to see the many rooms where Beatles would have stayed. The main meditation hall is full of graffiti and very lively. Should visit this once at least.

title: Cool place to explore
review: If you're in the area and have some free time this is a very cool place to just wander around and explore. It must have been quite the place in its day when it was actually a functioning ashram. Now it's just abandoned buildings, with a very cool vibe

title: Absolutely beautiful space, ruins and art
review: The ashram itself is crumbling away, but it is fun to explore, you could spend hours walking about and finding new and interesting things.

title: A place not worth visiting
review: I had lots of hope of this place but it is actually a place in ruins. There is nothing to be seen, except for broken down ruins where Beatles group used to stay. The entry fee is very high Rs 150 but what you get in return is almost nothing.

title: Amazing place ...amazing potential.
review: The area is absolutely fantastic. You can reach the temples walking the street on the back of the area. There are 2 entrances. The main entrance is easy to find. The second one is more difficult to find. Keep on walking till you see a path marked with white stones and follow it!

title: It was OKAY...
review: Frankly, I expected more from this place compared to what it was. There are ruins of what was once an aashram. Some of the graffitti was good. But not worth the entry ticket they charge! Plus, visit the place when you have a company. Going alone might not be the best idea. Not a place that you would regret not visiting.

title: Taking foreign tourists very often.
review: One of the best place to visit out from the din and dust.

title: Artistic Paradise
review: If you are visiting Rishikesh and not visiting Beatles Ashram then you must have missed some of the great arts. It's wonderful place to spend some of your quality time.

title: A must for Beatles fans
review: It's a little pricey (600r) but ultimately worth it to see where the Beatles wrote a lot of the songs from the White Album.

title: Beautiful spot on the bank of Ganga
review: Best place to showcase your photography skills in luxury green atmosphere.Graffiti artwork at the beatles ashram is also one of the famous thing.Now it’s deserted but with lush green ambience in the suburban alleys of Rishikesh will greet you inside.

title: Beatles Ashram Rishikesh
review: The ashram is now the gateway to a lion preserve and little remains of The Beatles visit. Yet it’s cool to sit inside the #9 pod where it’s said Lennon wrote Revolution #9. The dilapidated cement barn is worthy of a visit for Camera action of Beatles and Maharaja graffiti. A must see when in Rishikesh, budget 90 minutes and an easy hike from Laxman Julha. Beware the 600+ rupee admission cost.

title: One of the best touristy things I’ve ever done
review: We spent a couple of hours wandering around the Beatles ashram and loved it.

title: My Yoga Journey
review: My favorite place Chaurasi Kutiya known as Betal Ashram in Rishikesh. I have many many memories inside of that, my art, my lyrics, my slogan, my sign, my poems and most of my energy is there....

title: My memories
review: I took my first meditation training about 40 years back at this The Beatles Ashram  also known as Maharishi Mahesh Yogi's Ashram. At this time this place requires lot of attention. This could be converted to the world's center for meditation. If some one is interested in teaming up with resources please contact me Lalit Jain ( in Canada)   at jainL@shaw.ca

title: Awesome place with lot of graffiti work..
review: the Ashram is abandoned and its inside the national reserved park. since it attracts lot of people as a tourist place, the entry is allowed. It has lot of graffiti work on the walls of ashrams buildings. it worth of 2-3 hours visit.

title: So peaceful
review: This was a big tick on my bucket list. so beautiful and you could feel the energy of the place. Such a shame it has been abandoned though.

title: in the footsteps of the Beatles
review: if you go to Rishikesh, then you must visit this place.

title: Abode of peace
review: I went to the beatles ashram in February. The ashram is located on a hill adjacent to Ganga. Make sure to carry your student ID card for a discount on the entry fee. The ashram is abandoned and as you walk through the buildings, you cannot help but admire the beauty of the entire scene. Check out the graffiti in the buildings and auditorium

title: crazy admission fees for westerners
review: Not worth going - there is nothing to see.

title: For true Beatles fans only
review: I was frankly disappointed.  There is not a single building that is not crumbling beyond repair.  There is only 1 mural painted on the wall and thats the tribute to the Fab Four.  No pictures, artwork or anything.  For INR150/- I expected a lot more. For Non Indians it is INR 600/-

title: Cool, slightly expensive, a little hard to find
review: We visited after trying to locate the Ashram several times. We actually went to the entrance to the 'Tiger Reserve' twice, before returning to enter the Ashram.

title: Hauntingly beautiful abandoned ashram  - go for the architecture and quiet natural setting.
review: Hauntingly beautiful abandoned ashram  - go for the architecture and quiet natural setting.

title: Without visiting Beatles, Rishikesh tour is incomplete
review: An amazing mix of nature and spirituality.Lots of beautiful paintings(1 mural) were painted in the wall of ashram.  Peaceful place.Simply awesome.

title: Ruins of an erstwhile Asram
review: All that is left of the Beatles Ashram are ruins. This placed was apparently shut by Govt and reopened for public a few years back. It's a fairly big place and will take around an hour or two to cover. It's has loads of kutirs ( medication chambers) and some ruined structures. There are lot of graffiti work which one can come to check. That apart there is not much to do out here.

title: good place to visit
review: the ashram is good but entry fee is high. you can spend full day here. not must visit place but if you want to know about  Beatles then visit here.

title: A Day in the Life.
review: Beautiful, spacious area. Wonderful for those who love to snap photos for social media with art pieces everywhere. But also great for those who just want to get away and chill in solitude. Such a vast area that you rarely bump into other travelers/ tourist. nice rooftops to hang out on, fun rooms and buildings to explore, incredible nature to submerse yourself in. A bit price at 600 INR, but can be an all day excursion.

title: For the Beatles fan or as a lovely outdoor walk
review: I will admit that I am a HUGE Beatles fan- so take that into account. I could not wait to stand inside hut number 9, and search for all of the wonderful art pieces. 2 hours flew by on my first visit - so I went back a second time. I loved taking my time to wonder through all of the crumbling buildings. This place must have been amazing when it first opened.

title: Ruins with Art
review: To be frank, there is not much left to the ashram, only collapsed structures. Artists had graffiti over most of these fallen structures.

title: Fab place to visit for the fan of the Fab 4
review: What an amazing place - it must have been an oasis of nature, calm and spirituality when it was functioning in the 60s. The ashram is very big. For The Beatles fans, it will be a treat to visit, with all the art to commemorate them. Go and have a nice few hours walk and try to feel the vibes of the Liverpool lads :) I loved it.

title: Really interesting compound - great architecture and grafitti
review: This place is totally worth a visit if you're in the Risikesh area. You can imagine the peace and love hippie days with the Maharishi and the Beatles. It's a pity the Indian government doesn't turn this into a hostel - it's a great location on the Ganga and the stone pods would make great rooms. The grafitt art in the meditation hall and on the surrounding buildings is super cool. Fun to walk around all the abandoned buildings.

title: Located in the holy "Valley
review: Located in the holy "Valley of the Saints", the International Academy of Meditation, also called the Chaurasi Kutia ashram,

title: Worth entry price.
review: 600 rupees for foreigners, but the beautiful paintings and interesting buildings are worth the entry cost. Its officially open from 9am-5pm, but you could jump the fence if you wanted to get in earlier/later/for free. Not very busy, but allow plenty of time to walk around and see as much as possible.

title: A must see treasure...
review: Maharishi Maheshyogi made this masterpiece in the 1960s...it become famous as Beatles Ashram after Beatles visited the Ashram in 1968.

title: Underwhelming
review: Overpriced to get in do did not go. Other people said not worth it. From looking in on yhe outside very run down... such a pity.

title: Beatles ashram
review: Looks like a beautiful ashram however they want to charge foreigners 600 rupees where Indians pay 50-100, so I didn't visit it

title: Good Vibes & Graffiti inside the Ashram
review: We were visiting this Ashram 12 people, so we got a group discount and were paying only for 10 people. Thanks to our local Indian guide who made a deal with a security guy. But I must say 600 rupees is worth the price for the entrance. We spent inside around 3 hours, but I recommend to spend all the day and have a picnic there. Take food and a blanket to sit on - there is no cafe or bar inside. It is really good vibes inside the teritory of the Ashram. Perfec for meditation, long walking and finding all of these beautiful graffities.

title: It became a zoo now
review: Used to be an abandoned ashram that anyone could enter and explore or meditate if you wanted, but not anymore. Pay about 10 dollars for admission.

title: Beatles ashram
review: I visited here as part of a trip with back2nature holiday.

title: Ehhhhh too late
review: I guess I was too late to visit this place. The entry fees seems high and there is not much to do. But if the weather is good you might go here for a walk or to read a book. The ashram is in a dilipidated situation and has been ruined by the grafiti.

title: Simply Fab!
review: If you’ve heard of the Beatles and you’re in Rishikesh you simply must visit this tranquil place where the Beatles came in 1968 to stay as guests of the Maharishi. Recently opened to the public there is a surprising amount to see but it is what happened here, rather than what remains, which is of real significance. Whilst the Beatles were here they wrote at least 35 songs (some writers put it as high as 48) and it was their most prolific period of songwriting ever. Two thirds of the White album and two songs from Abbey Road were written here as was John Lennon’s Jealous Guy, although originally he called the song Child of Nature. It was to be the last time all four Beatles were together outside the UK. Entry is 600 baht.

title: Best Place for Meditation
review: The most important feature of this place in solitary is its consolation. This ashram, which is situated in the lap of nature, connects you with nature.

title: Very cool
review: The energy in the ashram had high vibrations. So much history left behind. The graffiti and paintings were pretty cool. If you go early first thing in morning before guards get there. Won't charge the 600 rupees.

title: Beautiful!
review: This place is just amazing! It is beautiful--and there is a lot of graffiti  style artwork painted there, which actually adds to the wonder of being there. So happy I went!

title: Music Fans, Artists and Yogi alike may find inspiration here.
review: Its too bad that this location isn't listed under its proper name; Maharishi Mahesh Yogi Ashram. With that being said is is abandoned. And a bit of a challenge to find. As there are no signs for it... but there are signs for the Tiger Reserve that it is associated with.  I asked the guard if this was the Beatles Ashram and he said "oh yeah, its that too". Prices are again different for foreigners and locals, 650 rupees for a foreigner and substantially less for a local tourist. I did read that you can enter through the back gate but, they do have some ticket, spot checkers t/o the complex.

title: Beatles Ashram
review: Swarm Ashram now know as the Beatles Ashram, highly recommend if your a fan or not. Amazing to know your walking the same path that the iconic Beatles did.

title: Good place to visit if u like beatles
review: Hi,

title: See where the Beatles Meditated & Wrote Dear Prudence
review: This is a magical place with so much potential.  It is run down and no longer an active ashram, but you could see so how this would have been the place to meditate and get inspiration.  I loved roaming the grounds and standing in the meditation hive of the Beatles.  Entry fees go from cheap for Indian senior citizens, to Indian citizens to the most expensive for foreigners.  Worth a visit even so.

title: good but over priced
review: place was great but 150 rs ticket very high. if you're interested in The Beatles you can visit. in rishikesh we stayed 4 days and visited every place

title: Not worth the drive.
review: The Beatles Ashram is probably a good place for you to visit if you are a Beatle's fan. They charge you entry fees but they don't maintain the property at all. There was no guard there and the bunch of guys who collect the entry fee weren't in uniforms & it felt more like an illegal collection because of their demeanour. The Ashram is nothing great either. The graffiti however is mind blowing and the only really good part of the entire visit.

title: Must Visit place in Rishikesh
review: One of the must visit attractions in Rishikesh, you can feel the amazing energy and beauty here !!

title: Expensive
review: By the way place is so beautiful .there is 84 (kutiya) for meditation which mahrishi Mahesh yogi used for there meditation.but 200 for Indians and700 for Western is unnecessary expensive.

title: If you are a Beatles fan, this is a must go.
review: It costs 600 rupees, quite expensive in comparison to other things in the area. It's an abandoned place. Expect mosquitos, big plants, mug, falling buildings and even bats. BUT DON'T MAKE THIS FRIGHTEN YOU TO GO. The 84 meditation chambers made with little ganga stones and the halls worth the visit. You can get inside the meditation chambers and stay there for a few minutes.

title: Well Hyped place - Dont why they charge so much
review: Location of this place is not well marked. Directions in google gives the right turn where turn is not available. Wherr the actual right turn is there is no marking. Actual  right turn is at place where there is big board of Rajaji National park. When you reach the place you dont even find the board of Beatles Ashram. Entry fee is 150 rupees for Indian and 600 rupees for foreigners. This is a loot, I dont understand why they have put entry charges so high.  Not even a person was available on Gate.

title: Magical Overgrown Ashram
review: If you are a Beatles fan or interested in unusual buildings then definitely come and visit. There is some great graffiti art to see and the view from the top of the largest building is well worth the stair climb. It is a little bit off the beaten track, a little pricey for foreigners to visit and there are no amenities but I found the place to be quite magical. It is a real shame that the jungle is taking over because it would have been an amazing place to stay.

title: Artist's Paradise
review: If you love Beatles and art then it's a must visit destination. It's very close to the bank of river Ganges and the place is divine. Peace would seek you here and you wouldn't be surprised to have an epiphany about why the legends came down here and how it could have been a transitional experience for them. The graffiti painted across the place is a constant reminder of the experience and vibes the place radiates.

title: Abandoned and not taken care of, but worth a trip
review: The paintings and sayings are beautiful, but the place itself doesn't have upkeep or restoration, so paying $600 rupees to get in is a bit of a rip off but the experience makes it worth it.

title: Peaceful
review: I did not actually go inside. I took pictures from outside. The walk to the Ashram is very nice, as is the little garden outside.

title: Beatles Ashram
review: Big and interesting, especially if you're interested in The Beatles

title: Oldest Ashram
review: A lil broken down but it is the ashram in it's rawest form. Art everywhere, exploring the ruins is exciting. Do keep in mind tickets are 600rs for foreigners.

title: Overpriced ticket.
review: If you will charge 15o rs to go see the place nobody will go there.it could be cheaper than you charging.by the way place was good

title: For lovers of the Beatles
review: I would call this place historic given the strong influence the Beatles had on rock music and the fact that they spent some time in India. The buildings in disrepair after the Maharishi left, have a charm and neglect that take you back to when this would have been a throbbing, "in" place. I like the current state, though other visitors feel that it should be maintained. The trees and growth give this a dreamy, lost look from years ago but you get an idea of the way life was lived when they were here. Explore with your earphones playing the White Album and get drawn into a world of  blackbirds, weeping guitars, racoons, revolution, and sexy Sadie.

title: Cool place but needs looking after!
review: Cool place to visit, hung Liverpudlian myself interested to see the place which inspired the Beatles song writing.  Entrance is quite expensive for what it is; a derelict building .  It could be amazing if it was maintained and had a bit.kore explanation about it.  The street art and graffiti in so e places really cool and thought provoking, in other parts is just plain vandalism.  It is easy to see that at one point in time this place created creative unblock and is a mystical place to visit.  I just hope the owner don't let it get too overgrown and run down.

title: Entry fees! No longer free!
review: The last time I had visited this abandoned ashram it had no entry fees but that was ages back. Nowadays Indians and Foreigners are charges to enter (differential charges of course where the Foreigners pay more - seems unfair to me). However, this is a place I like so much that I do not mind paying the entry fees. I can spend a whole day here. The area is so huge you can spend a long time over here!

title: Nostalgia in abundance
review: I missed the turn off to get to this ashram. Turn right at the large sign for tiger park, there is no indication for the Beatles ashram. It's worth the600 Rs entry fee if you are a fan and you want to step back in time. The dilapidated scene engenders a eerie and melancholic feel of days long gone. It's hard to imagine the magic and tranquillity there must/may have been. Walk all the way through the park. The are only one or two signs explaining the Beatles time there. But that's it. Apart from 'the cathedral'. Graffiti art work is nice.

title: Not worth it
review: They charge tourist 4 times the price Indian pay just to see some neglected structures. Totaly bad deal

title: Don't pay. Jump the fence in the back.
review: Apparantely it's 600 rupees entry.  I recommend going in through the back way as this place has no real reference to the beatles other than a sign and some graffiti on the walls.  It's a nice, nostalgic area to stroll through for 25 minutes, that's about it.

title: Great place to visit
review: Total calm. I just saw 5 people during the two hours I spent there. You can walk around and discover chambers. Also you can be in touch with nature. If you go during monsoon, carry a mosquito repellent. They will follow you everywhere!

title: Primarily for the Beatles Fan...
review: Maharshi mahesh yogi Ashram, which is famously called Beatles Ashram as they lived here for a while . Built like igloos, many of those small units , dedicated for each of permanent members of ashram, gives a different experience... its in the midst of jungle, offer peaceful and calm atmosphere for meditation.. now ofcourse abandoned .. you see many Westerners who are Beatles fan visiting the Ashram... I don't recall exactly but there is heavy entrance fee as well..

title: Wonderful graffiti
review: The ashram is abandoned and falling apart completely but the graffiti left by fan groups is just mind blowing.

title: Pure Magic...
review: Fantastic place with it's own speciel living spirit...go there and be dazzled <3

title: For lovers of urban exploration
review: Well worth a trip out here if visiting Rishikesh - especially if you're interested in urban exploration, street art and music!

title: wow love this place
review: this is the abandoned ashram of the Maharishi and where the Beatles stayed to get enlightened and learn.  Its a huge place try to get some one to walk you around as you could miss all the important things if you don't know where to walk and what to see.

title: Dilapidated MahaRishi Ashram
review: It was Maharishi Ashram and renamed to Beatles Ashram as they stayed here for quite some time. Entry fees of150₹ is quite high for the place which is almost ruined.

title: Worth the Risk/  Here you encounter Number 9
review: This Ashram is closed for the public, but you can ask locals to call the guard if he is not there to open the gate for you for something inexpensive.

title: Beautiful buildings lost in nature
review: Such a beautiful place to wander around for a day.  Between the graffiti and interesting architecture, there is much to see and photograph!

title: Shameless cash grab.
review: I would give this place five stars if it wasn't for the ridiculous entry fees. I'm so lucky I was in Rishikesh three years ago and was able to pay a guy 50 rupees to unlock the gate so I could go in and walk around this otherworldly site. (Really cool to see the river rock meditation huts and, on top of the dilapidating dormitories, the chanting chambers.) Now the place has been taken over by the Rajaji Tiger Reserve and the organization has set the ridiculous entry fees of 150 rupees for Indians and 600 rupees for foreigners. I was in Rishikesh a couple of weeks ago and went there with an Indian friend. Of course, in true Indian style, my friend tried to bargain with the guy at the ticket window and the guy actually said: "Europeans (ie. white people) have taken so much money from India, so we're going to take money from them." So there you go. Of course my friend brought up the logical argument that it was "Europeans" that made the, ahem, BEATLES ashram famous. As for the 150 rupee Indian fee, the Indian entry fee for the Taj Mahal is 40 rupees, so that puts that into perspective. Everybody is being ripped off. It's all too bad, because this is one of the highlights of Rishikesh and interesting to see the historical place where it all started.

title: Expensive and useless
review: No reason to walk all the way there as there is nothing much to see. The long walk ends at the entrance to the abandoned ashram. Tourists are churched 600 rupees. Save them

title: Cool place
review: Was pretty cool to wander around the abandoned site, especially with its rich history (and especially if you're a Beatles fan). However, the entrance fee is a bit of a rip off, especially since it's 4 times that of what Indian nationals have to pay!! Even entry into historic city halls and forts in India aren't that pricey.

title: Nice place
review: This is a nice place to go for meditation and yoga.  This is a very peaceful place.  it is worth trying and enjoying.

title: How much!
review: Lovely walk down here along the river but R600 to get in. You have to be kidding!  Lonely Planet 2016 says R100 - now that's inflation!!

title: Well that was weird
review: If you're expecting an active , living shrine to the Beatles , don't go . If you like the idea of abandoned , ethereal beauty , this could be right up your mountain path . It is completely abandoned and I was the only person there , which added to the slightly eerie feel . It is ridiculously expensive for foreigners , 600 rupees , considering that there is zero maintenance. But , I have no regrets , walk down to the banks of the Ganga , see photo.  Again haunting , beauty  , just wish I was a better photographer .

title: Amazing one
review: Beatles ashram is one of the ancient habitat of Beatles the we can see lots many Beatles huts not then 100 may b

title: Surprise😐
review: After entering the areal I was really surprised that whole areal are just ruins. After payment 600 rupees I assumed that  areal will be nicely maintained from the money they charge the tourists. Obviously, it is not that case. Except one picture of Beatles there is nothing what reminds old good times with Beatles. Make sure you ask people for the way to the main etrance not to end up on the wrong gate.There are no signs for dirrection and google maps shows wrong etrance gate. But honestly, you may skip this whole attraction and use money more wisely, nice dinner for example.

title: A peep into antiquity
review: Beatles is a mixed bag...at one moment you are in awe of the entire structure and the landscape...the very next moment strange thoughts come upon you when you see those weird pieces of art...must have been rich during its time but sad to see the dilapidated state it is at present...must visit attraction

title: Not worth the money
review: The entry ticket for Indians is 150rs.and for foreigners is 600. The ashram is abandoned,you can see meditation caves and lots of graffiti. The concept is interesting but it is not worth 600rs

title: The babas
review: This place was nice before,now you pay to entrance and is not even clean,very expensive by the way !!!!!

title: Sad sight
review: A music lovers pilgrimage site, now located in a Tiger Sactury. Derelict and abandoned but still has the kutirs of the famous 4. Drawings and graffiti by John Lennon and Paul McCartney still on the walls. Beware the different entry fees for locals and foreigners!

title: Historical
review: Amazing, you can spend whole day looking at beautiful concert halls filled with unique pictures on the walls. A complete 3-D effect.

title: a abandoned hippy place
review: some abandoned buildings full with wall writtings...

title: A must-see for all Beatles and music fans!
review: I had been to see the ruins of the ashram before, but now that the park is more open to visitors and the paths have been cleared, it is much easier to see everything. Additionally, there is so much great artwork on the walls that the whole place is like a giant art gallery. There is a real spiritual feeling here, and knowing that so much of the White Album and some of Abbey Road was written in this very spot is a real thrill. The meditation caves are really interesting and are in good condition.

title: Piece of heaven
review: Powerful, peaceful place. Living so much mystery, energy here. My batteries were recharged fully after a long day. I planned to look around originally but I found myself being there 2-3 hours by walking aimlessly. Go and visit definitely!

title: Open art gallery
review: This is where The BEATTLES stayed to get away from the people nod to find spiritual healing away from it all. I recommended this place, take your time no make sure your phone is charged so you can take video's and lots of pictures.

title: One of a kind place!
review: Beautiful ashram. It's a very quiet place. Very different from other ashrams in rishikesh. Not too far from Ram jhula.

title: Pretty cool
review: We loved it!! Wish they would restore the buildings! Pretty fascinating domes and chill vibes! The beginning of the ashram is boring but once you get to the end of it, it gets very interesting! Paintings, graffitis, buildings all were very cool! I recommend visiting it.

title: A Real Must-See!
review: There's something about the place that is calming and relaxing. I'm not into spirituality myself but you get a great feeling walking around the old meditation pods and outdoor areas. The ashram is set above the Ganges river and is very quite, and is large enough that you don't really see that many people there. If you're a Beatles fan then the experience is even greater! I'd definitely go again when back in the area!

title: Die-hard Beatles fan? Then it's a must see.
review: So this place is pretty interesting. Notice: the entry fee for foreigners is extremely overpriced at 600 rupees. If you're a Die-hard Beatles fan though it's still a must see in my opinion.

title: Get lost to be found here
review: Amazingly peaceful place. Heaven for photographers. It is just 4 kms from.lakshman jhula and around 1 km from ramjhula. One can easily go walking. Try to explore as much as you can and these doms have beautiful paintings inside. Whether you are a beatle's fan or not you need to go there for tha sake of art. Some amazing artists from all around the world have painted down the walls. Thousands of paintings are ready to captivate you. Go with a camera, in the morning, because this place needs more than couple of hours.

title: A waste of money!
review: A great place to visit the one or two caves where the Beetles stayed in but the rest of the walk is just the same stuff. We don't think the 600 rupee price per tourist justifies a walk amongst caves.

title: abandoned and not maintained well
review: To enter this place, foreign tourist should pay Rs 600 and I think it is very overpriced, considering the condition of the ashram that abandoned and not maintained at all. This place mainly offering ruins and building that used to be the place of The Beatles to learning meditation. Only a few note on a board that shows the mark of The Beatles. The coolest thing in this place are the graffiti and painting made by many fans around the world of in the hall.

title: weekend visit
review: nothing much to see, all in dilapidated condition. why they are charging Rs 150/- for entry i dont know, no maintenance. Only the name of Beatles gives you a great feeling

title: Beautiful Artwork at the Ashram.  Stunning
review: The art done by Kyrie Maezumi, Pan Trinity Das and others is absolutely breathtaking.   As you wander up from the main office check out the main Beatles cave area to see one of the first gems there.  Continue exploring the property to discover more of the stunning artwork there.  Kyrie Maezumi is the daughter of the late Maezumi Roshi ( Zen Master from Japan) and so you'll find his photos inside of he cathedral area.   A must if you are going to Rishikesh.

title: Big and interesting, especially if you're interested in The Beatles
review: The area and building are run down and derelict now. They have been abandoned for decades and there is graffiti everywhere. Some of the buildings are elaborate, with mosaics and meditation chambers, but only the shell of them remains. A big pricey at 600 rupees though for what it is. There is a possibility of sneaking in area the back area at the very rear of the premises. But don't let the guard in the green uniform see you though as he sometimes asks for tickets.

title: amazing place !!
review: My second favourite place to visit in Rishikesh (after one waterfalls :P) . Its so beautiful and the money goes to the Rajaji tiger reservation so all good with paying 600rupees haha .. Beautiful big place full of streetart, amazing poieces of art here. U can also meditate here .. its very nice place. Felt in peace here ..

title: Cool place but overpriced
review: Cool place to wander round and explore. Some nice artwork and photo opportunities. However, entry fee (₹600 for foreigners, ₹150 for Indians) is crazy and not sure what it's paying for since there is clearly no kind of maintenance of the buildings. Overall good fun, and pretty unique, so if you like the look of it, it's probably worth the entry fee for the experience.

title: Great relaxing place
review: Really impressive deserted complex. Some nice art and good atmosphere. Covered in jungle. Lots of beatle references, though without that it would've been equally impressive. + it suppprts the tiger reserve

title: Worth it experience.. Must go!
review: It's a deserted ashram that the Beatles visited in the late 60s. It's a huge place in Rajaji Tiger Reserve.

title: Worth 600 rupees
review: I went around 4:30 and the light was perfect. Could spend days wandering around inside all the rooms and buildings. After an hour or so I was too tired to care anymore. Great photos and some good vibes.

title: Amazing and beautiful place!
review: I'm so happy I decided to go here! This place is so beautiful. The architecture is amazing and I'm imagining that this place must have been heaven-like when it was up and running. Come early in the morning or at sunset. The light was beautiful then and also much nicer to walk around when not too hot. I think it was definitely worth 600 rupees. They weren't open when we came around 7 in the morning but they were kind enough to let us in (it was our last day in Rishikesh), so we got the place to our selves. The paintings all over is amazing and the buildings are so cool!

title: Exploration not so cool
review: Guide lines on Beatles Ashram for travellers and art lovers:

title: Interesting but shame there are no favilities
review: So this ashram was originally where Transcendental Meditation started & loads of 60s stars including the Beatles, Mia Farrows sister & other pop stars came to hang out.

title: Shoddy but still interesting!
review: I heard the Beatles Ashram was now an official tourist attraction with proper entry fee, so I was expecting it to be well maintained with the money it is making. This is definitely not the case! Before you go, just make sure you're not expecting some pristine ashram because it's quite the opposite!! I guess they just "let it be". Lol.

title: Absolute wow!!
review: My in laws stay at Haridwar, and visiting the Beatles Ashram had been high on my list of things to do ever since I read about it in Autocar Magazine.

title: Too expensive
review: This complex, once used by Maharishi and where the beatles and others stayed in the 60´s is now, as was told by the local guide, a government place and it is not in very good conditions. It closes at 17:00 and it is not far from laxman jhula bridge. just a little stroll at the Ganges margin and you get there. If you did not see the other sites in Rishkesh, go, otherwise, let it for last. The entrace is too expensive compared to other sites in India.

title: The ultimate experience
review: Got to visit there on our last day in rishikesh in quite hurry but it's the best experience of whole stay in rishikesh...You would be seeing an era...A history ...A legacy left behind...The stone huts...Old ashram structures.... Paintings by the visitors...You would long to go back to the time when this area was alive... Spirituality, silence and peace in the air.... Government has taken that over and it's out of maintaining for long...It really shows the pathetic insensitivity of our government to the old monuments and places of historical importance​...And the way to go there too is not good...It doesn't feel that grand from the main entrance but do go inside to visit the ashram...The nominal ticket charges and the long road that you travel to reach there( by foot) is worth the effort....And on the you would be luckily seeing the ram jhulaand parmarth temple too .....

title: Must see when in Rishikesh
review: I was really skeptical if I should go in or not as they charge 600 INR to go in but it was fully worth it... I was really sad that this Ashram isn't operating anymore as it is really beautiful and has got a great vibe.... Now it's full of amazing graffitis. Go in an explore and get lost in its beautiful surroundings.

title: A walk back in time
review: Cool place to visit but would help if there was more information available to understand what transpired during the Beatles' stay at the Ashram. Everything currently available is hearsay - mostly.

title: "Graffiti & Images in Deserted Buildings only but still a great place to see"
review: This is the Ashram where the Beatles stayed when they came to India in the 60's. It is now a part of Rajaji National Park. There is a ticket you need to buy at the entrance. The place is deserted & only visited by music lovers. The old meditation hall,  residential area & other buildings have graffiti and images of the Beatles. Very few people in. But it is a must visit for music lovers especially the fans of The Beatles.

title: A place to discover and to explore
review: The place is not that easy to find as there are no signs and it is a bit lost in the forest. But if you follow the path along the Ganges at Parmarth Niketan Ghat downstream until the end, you will finally arrive to the gate of the Beatles Ashram. The entry fee for international tourists is 600 RS. There is a lot to discover and the place has its own very special atmosphere and vibe. The Beatles are omnipresent through the amazing wall paintings that can be found in different buildings. I won't tell too much here as I leave it to everyone to discover this place at their own. This is definitively a place I will remember.

title: Fantastic
review: Beatles visited here around 1986 to learn the transcendental meditation . There's some stunning graffiti inside the premises didn't expect the ashram to be this beautiful. Loved every nook and corner of it.  A must visit if you're in Rishikesh.

title: So glad I made the effort
review: It's not easy to find and at the end of a hot frustrating day in Rishikesh I was almost ready to call it quits. Really glad I didn't! There's something mesmerizing in witnessing big structure being eaten by the jungle and the great Graffiti art add to this.
