This would have been a spectacular place in its day and now it's just as spectacular but for different reasons. But remember safety is not a priority as western tourist might expect. 6 stories up, no need for a railing, stairs collapsing, no worries.

title: PEACE
review: All you can find at this place is soulful peace and tranquility. The Ashram is located a little far and can get scary as one has to walk for almost a hour to reach there. But the walk towards the Ashram is full of nature and peace.

title: Winter Time Happiness
review: The best time to vist is winter because of the blossom and less grass around. If you are here to record a video for your youtube channel or any other then let me tell you that you are at the perfect spot for that. The place has its own authenticity and also the beatles touch. Good place for recording and photography.

title: Fantastic!
review: A must visit if you're in Rishikesh. There's a certain ambience to the place and some of the art is beautiful. We spent quite a few hours here, wandering round and admiring the beauty of the place. Could have quite easily spent a few hours more. The entry fee for 'foreigners' is 600 rupees. Some people complained about it, but I believe it's worth it - I may well even go back again before I leave Rishikesh!

title: Totally radical
review: This is one serene place away from the crowded Rishikesh. It is abandoned location but totally safe. There is no proper directions for Beatles Ashram but you can find it as the entry gate of Rajaji Forest Reserve since it is inside the reserved forest. There is an entry fees and hence very less crowd will be there.

title: Just Awesome...!!!
review: Its inside the Rajaji National Park and has entry fees for Indians its Rs 150 and for foreigner its Rs 600 each. This place is away from the crowd and has no proper guidance we were misguided by Google Map but there is Board mentioning Rajaji National Park not Beatles Ashram.

title: A place lost in time and to nature and monkeys
review: After a boat across the Ganges and a pleasant walk you come to the Ashram (you would not stumble across it without knowing it was there). As a Beatles fan it was totally fascingating.  If you were not a Beatles fan there is very little there and my score would be lower.  Derelict buildings, the ever soiling graffiti were sad to see but the overall atmosphere of a place so significant to music but otherwise lost to time made for an unforgettable experience

title: Left out walks for great artworks .
review: Beatles Ashram as it is famously known is another name for Maharishi Mahesh Yogi's Ashram . Beatles visited here around 1986 to learn the transcendental meditation . The ashram now consist of old buildings , houses and is the home for one the most beautiful and creative artworks . The ashram is empty and now is the home for only the artworks . But there are worth a look .

title: Mystical place...
review: Must see!!! Ashram is situated at amazing location, don't miss roof terrace on the top of the building where the sleeping rooms were, on the right side of the path in the ashram yard...

title: Absolutely stunning
review: Didn't expect the ashram to be this beautiful. Loved every nook and corner of it. There's some stunning graffiti inside the premises, so don't miss stepping inside the deserted cottages, you might miss out on a surreal experience :)

title: Super Cool
review: My girlfriend and I enjoyed visiting the Beatles Ashram. There isn't a lot to do, but it was really cool to see. There were some amazing views from the top. I recommend checking it out.

title: Too expensive!
review: 600 rupies for this? Graffiti done a few months ago in the room of the Beatles, nothing really to see for me. I didn't pay to enter (the employee was sleeping!), but I would have not even pay 100 rupies!

title: Pricy but worth it!
review: 600 rupees for foreigners might feel a bit much but I can totally recommend the place. It has a very special energy over it, sure beatles were there but this place has more than that to offer.

title: Maharishi's Ashram
review: They call this place the Beatles ashram because they visited Maharishi Mahesh Yogi at his ashram.  Still a powerful place from all the people who meditated there. Sit in the meeting hall and close your eyes.

title: A run down place.
review: Needs better upkeep. Has its significance primarily due to the beatles group. Can be given a miss. Unless its one of the places you have planned to visit for historical reasons.

title: Fun to walk around the decaying ashram
review: I didnt expect to enjoy this place as much as I did.  The grounds are fairly run down these days but a number of graffiti artists have decorated the remains with amazing pictures that are fun to hunt out amongst the decaying buildings.  I would say its deff worth the entry price and you can enjoy yourself in there for hours checking out the amazing buildings around the place.

title: Bittersweet
review: A wonderful walk down memory lane for those of us that were transformed by the Beatles music. Who wasn't? There is a great clean up and restoration effort happening there- but it still has quite a way to go! It's not a government owned park and they are slowly but steadily working to bring it back to a inviting place. The graffiti artwork is awesome. The stone meditation rooms are cool!

title: Tranquil and inspiring
review: From the graffitis to the green forest, there's a different aura and no wonder the Beatles wrote some great tunes there. Away from the busy Laxman jhula, this place is (a forest reserve now) so calm and poised that you wouldnt stop imagining how Lennon or Paul would have walked around, what might have caught their attention and what not!

title: A walk in the past with the Beatles
review: This historic center has fallen into disrepair. It could be brought back to some of its former glory but it is passing into a jungle experience where you are charged for the privilege of walking the crumbling edifices So sad!

title: nostalgia filled space
review: The Beatles ashram has fallen into disrepair, but the atmosphere remains and one can imagine what it was like to be there back in the day.Artists have reinvigorated the space with great art, it is a time machine and a ,magical space where one becomes a part of the writing if the White Album.

title: Tranquillity in abundance
review: In love with this place that offers peace in abundance. I could only here the gushing water of Ganges & the birds singing. No wonder its also called Swarg Ashram. The story of Beatles attached to this places is amazing.

title: 600 Rupees well worth it
review: This place is huge and you could easily spend a few hours here and even get lost.

title: Nirvana!
review: This place although badly maintained, has a really different charm about it. This is probably because of the condition it is in right now. Most of it are ruins. When I went there, I was all alone and could spot no one except for the guards at the gate. You feel like its haunted! But again, it has a different feeling altogether attached to it. Probably the surroundings and the silence of the place, that takes you closer to nature, to earth. Peace!

title: Peaceful place
review: This place has an entry fee of 150... This is costly but It is worth a place to visit if you want to see some caves and the drawing . we can have good peace of mind provided the crowd is well behaved

title: A TM Ashram
review: I suppose that calling this the "Beatles Ashram" creates a better marketing message, but this was the Ashram of Maharishi Mahesh Yogi of TM fame, where the Beatles, among other super stars, once visited. Now it's a ruin being taken back over by the jungle. Kinda of interesting to take a walk around and look, but way overpriced for what there is to see.

title: Disappointing
review: A very disappointing place, there is nothing to see , no body lives in the ashram since a very long time, quite far, in the jungle, travelllers are requested not to waste time by visiting this ashram since it is closed since a very long time

title: Hard to believe this is no longer used
review: What an incredible experience in the middle of the Himalayas next to the Ganga. This awesome experience provides breath taking views if you go to the very top end of this ashram site and on the roof...close the the boundary fencing where sometimes you can see/hear the elephants.

title: Graffiti paradise
review: This is an old ashram taken over by jungle. Nobody lives here anymore. The graffiti by Milestoland and the caves are amazing. There's nothing related to "the Beatles" here apart from the caves they stayed in, and their songs scribbled or painted at few places, which makes it more of a marketing trick. But yes, this place has more of vibe factor. Good place for solo travelers.

title: Outdoor art gallery / great site seeing
review: I've been twice to the Beatles Ashram and every time, I find something new I didn't see before. This amazing abandon Ashram has a lot of charm and you can take some epic pics (yoga posers strike your cameras!). If you like street art and photographie, this is a must do attraction. A bit expensive to get in, but worth it.

title: A walk down Memory Lane
review: We visited Maharishi Mahesh Yogi's ashram where the Beatles went to meditate in 1968 along with Donovan, Mia Farrow and Mike Love of the Beach Boys. For many decades the ashram was abandoned and fell into disrepair but recently the government has turned it into a tourist attraction and called it The Beatles Ashram. Most interesting were the 68 bee hive shaped meditation huts the Maharishi had built from river rocks for the visitors to meditate in.

title: Not worth the hype
review: I was expecting the site to be better maintained for the price you had to pay to get in but it was more of a "ruin" than it was a site. There were some signs telling you what things were but it was more of photography opportunity than seeing the actual Ashram. If you have time to waste, I would go, but would not make a special trip if you are limited in cash or time.

title: Different place, complete city within itself
review: I have heard a lot about the Beatles Ashram and finally had the chance to visit the place on my last trip to Rishikesh. We planned our day such that we have a good amount of breakfast and then take the road to Ashram. The place is located on the road alongside the Ganga and is most the last Ashram on the road. There is a nominal ticket for visiting the place, Rs150/- each. The ashram is located at such a peaceful location and with lot of trees. The ashram had been abandoned long back is presently maintained by the Wildlife department. Most of the structures are still there and some of them have been damaged, as no care was taken over the year. The paintings on the walls and building are amazing and takes one to a different environment. Surely a place worth visiting if you want to have some time with yourself without any disturbance.

title: A nice surprise
review: Personally I don't like to go to crowded tourist attractions and therefore I really enjoyed a walk around this ashram. It was more like ruins of an ashram inside the jungle, with a lot of single huts. It has a nice mystic atmosphere

title: Must see in Rishikesh
review: This is one of those sightseeings that should be on must-see list of Rishikesh visitors. Nowadays abandoned, this ashram used to attract hundreds of people, who were staying either in private cells or in common campuses, which are still spread over huge ashram's territory, along with meditation halls, kitchens, etc.  Many different constructions, some of them of very unusual architecture, are covered with intricate graffiti works. To visit the Beatles Ashram you need at least two-three hours at your disposal, to be able to investigate every hidden corner of this amazing place.

title: Chaurasi Kutia Ashram (Formerly the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi Asharm)
review: The Maharishi Mahesh Yogi Ashram at Rishikesh is now called the Chaurasi Kutia Ashram and is a 5 minute drive from the Ram Jhoola. For those who grew up in the sixties and loved the Beatles, this place conjures up great nostalgic expectations. Unfortunately, the site is presently completely deserted, there are abandoned ruins, and not a soul to tell us anything about its history. It is now a part of the Rajaji Tiger Reserve and the fact that the rooms and the pathways were swept and clean were indicative that some sort of upkeep was indeed being done A steep entry fee of Rs. 150 (foreigners Rs. 600) ensures that even ghosts keep away. The kutia (chalet), probably the one which The Beatles used, is marked. The only other interesting place is a room - probably a meditation room, with graffiti on all the walls. It is a large estate, with lots of greenery but is a little scary if you are alone.

title: Worth all the time and patience
review: चौरासी कुटिया --- that's what the Beatles Ashram has been named by Rajaji National Park authorities ... Even though the place has been very recently opened for public, the complete ashram holds the same charm I believe it used to live decades back ... all the Transcendental Meditation which was preached and practised can still be felt in every corner of the Ashram ... See it to Believe it :)

title: An off-beat ashram that surprises u !
review: Perched somewhere in the dense rajaji tiger reserve is an ashram, the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi ashram or the Beatles ashram. It has ruins of the ashram, the painted meditation hall,maharishiji's bungalow and 84 meditation huts. But the trail and the greenery around the place is enchanting, with full of positive vibes and a sense of peace.

title: nostalgic
review: about 15-20 walks from swarg ashram in rishikesh, this is where Beatles came in the 82s and anyone who has grown up listening to them would feel a little nostalgic about this place. however, there is not much to see there now.

title: A must see
review: They said I would spend an hour inside - I was there 3 - I found it fascinating! It does cost 600 rupees to enter but well worth it in my opinion...

title: All You Need Is Love
review: A trip back in time. Amazing place....amazing artwork....peacocks strolling by....

title: Wonderful nostalgia
review: Visit 2 years running, great  if your a Beatles fan. This year is organised for tourists visits, paths have cleared somewhat, and there is minimal entry fee. Love all the wall painting/graffiti in the old Satsang hall.

title: Don't miss it!
review: People often leave it out but seriously this place is so so beautiful. Full of amazing, neglected buildings you can walk freely through and explore without barriers and there is so much incredible art to find.

title: Beautiful but abandoned
review: This is no doubt a stunning place.. the problem in my opinion is that they charge quite a lot of money for entering in a place that is completely abandoned and overtaken by nature (which looks great though)

title: What a whimisical little place!
review: I had low expectations for this place based on some reviews and the drastic price hike for foreigners, but after all was said and done it was worth every rupee. It's so lovely. We went in the middle of a storm which added a lil' excitement to our adventure. The art is phenomenal and there is plenty to explore. I couldn't find a dull moment. I will do this again if I am fortunate enough to visit Rishikesh again.

title: Worth the entrance fee
review: We really enjoyed our time there.  Make sure you listen to the White Album before you go. You will recognize where many of the lyrics came from.

title: You're here, you may as well! (But I mean that in a good way!)
review: I like the Beatles as much as the next guy but I'm no superfan by any means. The 600 INR ($9 USD) price tag gave me a bit of a pause (during this cash crisis in India-- #ThanksModi), since NOTHING costs that much in India, save the Taj Mahal. However, we went and actually spent 90 minutes there exploring the ruins. We arrived at 11 AM and were the only ones there for the entire time. Take your time and really get in there--there are some neat things to see, beautiful art, funny graffiti.  You came all the way here--definitely don't balk at the price hike. Even if you don't care about the Beatles at all, they're cool ruins to explore!

title: Not straightforward to get to...
review: We were on the south of Laxmann Jhula (the upriver bridge). We were told that if we followed the road down river we would come to a group of autos( Tuk tuks) and that they would take us to the Beatles Ashram.  There were no autos to be seen. We walked back to Laxmann Jhula and hired a white landrover to take us there, wait, and bring us back.

title: Visit gone waste
review: After purchasing ticket no soul was there in complex. No guide ,no indicators except monkeys. After spending half hour there ,we came disappointed. Yes a calm and quite place.

title: INTERESTING PLACE
review: The buildings have not been maintained (pity, as it could be the most stunning ashram still), but one certainly gets a sense of what it was like when it was in use.  The setting is lovely - in the forest - and it was very peaceful walking around and seeing the different areas.

title: Strange place and very intresting.
review: It needs to see it. It was like community with a lot of people. Good to see and understand how spiritual life is grow in all world throught the Beatles and another people.

title: Worth it!!
review: Yes, this place is run down but I think that's part of its charm. You can run around and explore to your heart's content. I would definitely go back here.

title: A bit of history: now saved as a tiger preserve
review: Due to the tireless efforts of a dedicated man, this historical site has now opened as a tiger reserve and is being restored. The place reeks of history, with buildings surviving from the time of the Beatles visit in 1968 and beyond. One gets a real sense of it's importance as a spiritual place, as well. Restoration is taking place, clearing paths and gardens. Definitely worth a visit. plans are in the works for a cafe and gift shop in the future.

title: Over prices and in ruins
review: First of all the enterance fee was 600 rupees. Totally over priced! The ashram is completely run down and the only thing that indicates the Beatles had been there was a modern stencilled spray paint of there image. If you go to this ashram as part of a pilgrimage, expect a depressing view of a time gone by. A forgotten,  dilapidated ruin that promises a view of a great ashram. Avoid not worth it.

title: Transcendal Meditation
review: This was the best place to visit in Rishikesh

title: Blissful Experience
review: im a beatles fan. So this place was not one to be missed on my visit to Rishikesh. This place has a really great vibe to it. it was the ashrma where the beatles came down to for spiritual enlightenment back in 1968. This place is not a very crowded one as its deep into the woods along the banks of river Ganga. Its beautiful. Love beatles? go there! Love graffiti and art? GO GO GO!

title: dissapointing
review: it is located in beautiful surroundings but sadly its in a state of neglect and needs proper maintainence. recommended  mainly for hardcore beatles fan. There is nothing really inside other than graffitty on the walls.

title: Delicious food, amazing view n music
review: I can keep going here every time I'm in Rishikesh! Best cafe among all! The food was so delicious that we had to pack some to go for our friends to try. The view is simply stunning. Staff are very accommodating and wifi is excellent! You can sit here working on your laptop for hours and not feel bored.

title: What the heck!
review: The ashram grounds are now part of the offices/housing for the staff of the forest/park.  They wanted 600 ruppees to enter.  Would seeing the guard's laundry hanging on the line be worth it?  I decided ..NO.  I was unable to channel The Beatles vibrations here.  LOL.

title: straight out of indiana jones
review: its a wild place. the old ashram is now derelict with the jungle claiming it back. the graffiti is brilliant in parts and for beatle lovers its a pilgrimage. MUST SEE.

title: Holiday
review: Not so great about it as heard from ppl over d years. It is past n not as such which could inspire me. There r many more places n oldwr than this to visit n get inspired.

title: Nothing special
review: It is nice to see where they were during that time but is not possible see something different and in my opinion is too expensive to get in.

title: A Rishikesh must see
review: For everyone who ever loved the Beatles, this place is infamous for their short stay. The country has started to restore walk ways so you can see the various huts and buildings where Transcendental Meditation became popular.

title: Beatles asharam:: A soothing place
review: Beatles asharam is located in Rajaji Tiger Reserve.A soothing place to visit.Located in the midst of jungle it's a wonderful place to look up.The place offers beautiful wall paintings and quotes.Its quite far away from Rishikesh so u need a medium of transportation to reach the place.I really enjoyed and got rejuvenated after visiting the Beatles asharam.

title: Sight seeing
review: A good place to visit. Take car/taxi upto the ashram gate and take the road from the barrage.  Initial climb a bit steep. Worth a visit

title: Nice place but not good upkeep
review: This place can be developed as a cultural heritage site but the upkeep is bad. The entry too is restricted although we managed to visit for some time.

title: Should be developed
review: Had read a lot about this place in blogs and visited i,but apparently there are entry restrictions so could not see properly. I hope the government develops this as a nice tourist spot.

title: In a real jungle!
review: For me that I love Beatles, it was really nice to discover a place like that: it's in a real jungle from where you can see a wonderful Gange's view. Just an advice: bring with you some repellent, there are so many mosquitos!

title: Whaaat!
review: Well, ok the beatles had been here...but the beautiful graffiti walls amongst the decrepit ruins are like a treasure hunt. The entry ticket keeps away most including the drug seeking hippies of rishikesh, so you generally have the place to yourself

title: Hardly worth it
review: If you're desperate for some Beatles culture and history then by all means take the walk or taxi and have a look. However in my opinion pointless. An expensive ticket price for what is essentially a dilapidated house with no indication that the Beatles were ever there.

title: Visual orgasm.
review: The silence takes you on a different trip all together Aside of some outstanding works of art around, the place is paradise for those who wish to just wish to gulp in some fresh air.

title: Amazing!
review: We loved the Beatles Ashram. It was beautiful, so much exploring to do there. Make sure you give a few hours spare for being here. Nature at its finest, little surprises of artwork around the place and a big undercover area full of Beatles paintings and quotes etc. A truly spectacular place and worth the money to get in there!

title: beautiful grafitti
review: A vintage place of maharshi mahesh yogi where the famous band beatles visited .

title: like from another world...
review: I've been to the so called Beatles Ashram every time I came to Rishikesh. The ticket price for foreigners is very high compared to everything else in town. However, the experience can be magical. Walking through the decaying buildings with its unique setting and architecture is always and adventure as the jungle slowly takes over and provides a space for all sorts of animals, from exotic birds and peacocks, to monkeys and colourful butterflies. It is bigger than you might expect. So take some time for your explorations!

title: Loved this place
review: An interesting place to wander around it you like abandoned derelict buildings. Great murals on the walls and very peaceful. Take mosque to repellent, sun cream and raincoat if monsoon. Nice place to wander around for a couple of hours.

title: Being in history
review: If you are walking, it can feel like a long trek, and you may need to ask the way.  You will come to the end of the road, and a dry river - you need to walk up the dry river and you will see the Ashram on your right. If you come by car, you will have come the other way.

title: Not an attraction anymore.
review: Some years ago I bet this was a great attraction, but today it is just a waste of time.

title: Beautifull and early visit to Ashram taken back by jungle
review: Very nice visits of this historical Maharishi Ashram (that received the Beatels amongst many celebrities in the 60'ies) that has been taken back by the jungle since it was closed

title: nothing really special
review: Nostalgia maybe otherwise nothing really,  special about the ashram which is old, rugged dirty and now even expensive to get in.

title: History
review: Not much to see, no entry is allowed, surroundings are not clean, not easy to find, having some distance from the main part of the city...

title: Atmospheric time warp
review: Amazing place - all the buildings left as they were, the jungle slowly growing over them all. Hundreds of monkeys. Stunning place.

title: Forgotten Place
review: The Ashram once one of the main attraction to visit the city. I was not aware about the place and someone told me while i was visiting rishikesh. The place is closed and not kept well.

title: Maharishi Mahesh Yogi Ashram
review: Beatles have stayed here and composed many songs. It is a part of Rajaji National Park. There is no exciting thing to see and the entry ticket is overpriced.

title: Nice views and some graffities
review: It's a shame its abandoned even so its really nice to see the stuvas for meditation and just to feel the energy of the place. Walk through all roads and enter some buildings so you will see there were going on differents activities...

title: Left for the earth to claim back
review: I loved every part of the Beatles Ashram. The place is left in ruins and the jungle is slowly swallowing it and claiming it back, a truely beautiful sight, Some say it is a shame that the place is not put to good use anymore however I think the beauty of the place is witnessing the deteriorating state. Beautiful artworks and general graffiti shows something new to search and ponder with every deserted room. Well worth the visit. Entry fee is 600 INR for foreigners, take your camera and plan to explore for at least a few hours.

title: Could be a wonderful place was not so as imagined needs restoiration and a caffee or little restaurant
review: If this beautiful parc will be renovated it would be an atraction for many was not so inviting last year december

title: Magic
review: At 600 rupee pp, you have to be a real Beatles fan and understand the story behind the Beatles visit with the Maharashi. It was well worth it in our eyes, overgrown and mysterious only added to the magic and spiritual experience. Hunt deep for deep dark hidden passages for some real exploring. We were the only ones there, take at least a few hours to get round, your gonna need it.

title: Nice walk around
review: It was nice to walk around this site and imagine what it was like back in the day. It is not operating as an ashram but more as a tourist attraction however, we only saw one couple on our visit. The Beatles 'cave' (stone hut) is marked as such.  The entry ticket is steep.

title: Why?
review: I can heare the sound of a time that don´t exist anymoore. It´s so fantastic even now when everything is fallen down and the nature take over.  This should be a fantastic place. But why does the goverment just "Let it be"!!!

title: JUST OK not really worth it...
review: not much too see..  ashrams houses, some paintings on walls,one painting from john lennon, signed by him

title: Excellent spiritual place to discover
review: Peaceful and energetic place to discover by bioenergy explorers. However the site is wide and cannot be entirely visited; ask for guidance to one of the babas near the entrance. Some will show you the best meditation rooms and make you experiment special nadis meditation, particularly in the ovoid domes on the roof. Visitors will also enjoy the drawings made by the Beatles themselves as well as by other famous artists.

title: if you love graffiti, you should go there
review: its must visit place for people who love art and graffiti. i am not that fond of this thing but my friends were just because they were enjoying so much i also enjoyed with them

title: Cool spot for artists and tourists but weird energy
review: Ive been to the Beatles ashram a few times. Its is more a an art gallery than an ashram. Its cool to spend a few hours with friends and check it out. Also, a good place to take pictures and share with your friends. My yoga group and i took pictures of our poses in the main hall. There are usually interesting people to mingle with and discuss the art. However, bc Beatles left on a bad note there is still a bit of lingering weird energy. If you go to Rishikesh, it is def worth a visit with friends and a camera!

title: Nice place for a change
review: Nice place a bit off centre..approachable by car....the place visit cost INR 150 and it is worth exploring...graffities on wall and amazing place ....better to go in morning or early afternnon ...no entry after 4 pm..its in national park so u'll see bird, peakock and like me may just escape tiger strolling in its evening walk..

title: Magic
review: First I was not sure about visitung this Ashram because it is so famous and the entry is 650 Rupies but it is definately worthit to experience this magic place. It is hudge with a lot of caves and buildings with beautiful paintings. Plan enough time to go there...

title: Beatles ashram..memory lane...pun intended.
review: Walk along the Ganga worshipping ghats...follow the river and the crowded Ashrams.....and  tucked away into the edge of what is now a Wildlife sanctuary is the crumbling vestige of the Maharishi Mahesh yogi Ashram.

title: Interesting, Tranquil & Surprisingly Amazing Ruins
review: This Ashram officially known as “Maharishi Mahesh Yogi Ashram” or “Chaurasi Kutia” by the locals. It is located inside Rajaji Rashtriya Tiger Reserve. It is little more than ruins and consisted of meditation cells, a lecture hall, and a great number of purpose-built bungalows and egg shaped meditation huts. Now overgrown weeds, shrubs, and trees covered most of the territory and an eerie silence filled the air.

title: Nice landscaping
review: Maharishi returned his ashram to The forestry department after several decades of use, including visits by the Beatles and other popular songwriters. It's fascinating to see the amount of creativity that Maharishi's poured into the site, and the forestry department has done a noble job of landscaping and preserving the site.

title: Beautiful
review: Sad that such a beautiful place would be left to such disarray. An incredible atmosphere. Un worldly.

title: Step Back in Time and Imagine !!
review: So happy to have found this after walking 2 kms off track worth the wait.It's nostalgic, a little eerie but gets the time traveller in you spinning.I was allowed strictly 30mins inside.Great photos of a ruin now that shaped so much of the 60's outlooks and broadening acceptance of other countries offerings.I was over the moon to know i had made it and fulfilled another travel dream. They do come true.!

title: Graffiti Place
review: if u love art, this is best place to visit, u'll see lots of graffities there

title: Ridiculous...
review: The place is famous just because of the Beatles visit... it's far away walking from town and you pay (a lot!) the entrance to see garbage and ruins... Avoid... Avoid!

title: over hyped
review: No doubt the place is beautiful and all that and is peaceful but it is not well maintained. I did not like that the entry fee is not being put to good use.

title: Nikki
review: Incredible. Peaceful.  Amazing artwork.  Great architecture.  Highly recommend. Worth the 600 rupee they charge travellers.  Allow a few hours to really get the best out of it.

title: Good place to drop around
review: Famously known as Beatles ashram is abandoned place as the ashram falls under the area of Rajaji National park. Ticket cost is as entry fees to national park  (Rs 150) so dont confuse it with the fees for vistiting the ashram and found that it is not at all maintained. You will see around 80-90 small rooms built around ashram, where a person used to stay and meditate. You will find one big hall where many people have left their marks of creativity through paintings and poetry.

title: Unexplainably Groovy!
review: If you appreciate architecture and urban art, this place will amaze you.  Walk among the ruins and search for murals inspired by the most famous residents.

title: The mismanaged grandeur.
review: The place is great attraction for the Beatle fans as they had a fairly long stay & composed music here.

title: You can feel the history
review: It's a bit of a hike from town, but worth the effort.

title: Well worth a visit
review: I wanted to visit as I learned Trancendental meditation, my husband for the Beatles connection. Either way it's well worth half a day to explore. It's fallen into disrepair but that adds to the charm of the place. When we were there it was very quiet. Get a guide for 300 rupees as its a big site and you could miss so much. Now part of a tiger sanctuary I guess you could combine it with a safari.

title: Amazing Vibe
review: Now derelict, but lifted by some inspiring street art. Certainly worth a visit, but remember the place is not just about the Beatles. I've heard there are government plans to renovate the place, which doesn't make much sense to me.

title: Beatles
review: Visit to this place is well worth a visit. Fallen into disrepair but that adds the charm of this place. So many famous songs of Beatles were inspired by this place. You will see murals and graffiti taking you back to 1968. Recently is was in news also. spread over very big area, you may take guide for better appreciation of this place. May not be suitable for the children and senior citizens as you have to walk a lot and this place is away from the main city.

title: don't miss
review: a really nice place to spend about two hours or more taking pictures

title: Why would anyone keep it a secret?
review: Why would anyone keep it a secret?

title: Totally rip off
review: If you are a big fan of The Beatles and coming here was one of the main reasons to visit Rishikesh I guess you will pay the 600 rupees ticket at the entrance... I didn't.

title: Badly Maintained, No Trace of Beatles History
review: I'm a Beatles fan and on our last trip to Rishikesh, we decided to visit the Beatles Ashram. We reluctantly paid Rs. 300 per head as entry fee (which is steep for most places of public interest in India) and in turn expected to see the way Maharishi Mahesh had lived at the ashram and how Beatles would have spent their time here which in turn would have perhaps inspired some of their music as well. All we saw were some badly maintained 'caves' inside walls of which were painted with grafitti by some visiting Beatles fans. Other areas in the campus were totally unkempt with broken window panes, broken doors, etc. In case you are going in to know more about the Maharishi or the Beatles, you are going to be terribly disappointed. And in case you want to experience the view from the ashram, you can do so for free from an adjoining parcel of land which belongs to no one and overlooks the Ganges. BTW, I almost forgot to mention that the walk from the Jhula to the ashram is also filthy beyond Swarg Ashram.

title: Little piece of history
review: This place is hard to find and is in a deserted place. The entry fee is 150/- for Indians. The ashram is in a dilapidated state with rundown buildings and is non functional. Prefer to Visit in a group so you feel safe and cover the entire property. The place is covered with graffiti and tidbits from the time the beetles stayed at this place. Nice to see and go back in time.

title: Amazing and astonishing
review: Visited with friends... found this place very attractive... though this is abandoned but great graffities around the buildings made this place a new avatar... Beatels spent time here under maharshi mahesh yogi.

title: Great Photo Shooting Spot
review: We went to Beatles Ashram for Yoga photo shooting and i must say it turn out to be GREAT!! In December, the weather is little cold but despite of the cold weather, me and my friends were having fun taking photos in this beautiful place. Only concern is the newly implied entrance fees. 600 rupees is rather too much for a tourist spot in Rishikesh. If you love arts and nature, this will be a great place to visit.

title: What are you looking for?
review: This an historical site. What you see is: what is there. What you take away from your visit is an entirely different matter and, perhaps, a reflection of the way you view the world. Sitting on a hillside, just within the boundaries of the Rajaji Rashtriya Tiger Reserve, the ashram has fallen into a state of decay since its closure in the 1990s and nature has taken over. As with any historical site, it is the remains of buildings that are being viewed ... It is the living culture that's, perhaps, being imagined. This place was the heart of a movement (For a while) that became a worldwide phenomenon. Ever since I saw the pictures of the Fab Four with the Maharishi it has been a place of fascination for me. I was not disappointed as I walked the overgrown pathways and explored the derelict buildings with their graffiti covered walls. I was living my dream

title: Expensive for foreigners, but worth the trip
review: If the utterly ridiculous 600 rs entrance fee doesn't put you off, the place is definitely worth seeing. The disintegrating building are gorgeous, the location is beautiful and there's nice graffiti art as well. We went at 9 when it opens and there were hardly any people there, so it was a very relaxed experience. The little huts were my favorite, but I did enjoy all of it, including the amazing views from the balcony of Maharishi Mahesh Yogi's residence.

title: Must visit when in rishikesh... This is what made rishikesh .. What rishikesh is
review: Beautiful place.. To get lost with yourself ... Imagine somewhere John Lennon was actually sitting and rhyming white album...!!! Beatles cathedral ... And chaurasi kutia artworks are amazing.. Wow

title: A must do for any classic rock fan
review: The place is in a dilapidated state BUT worth a visit. The graffiti across walls is trippy and very colorful. One can visualize what a hallucinating place this would have been during its peak! A must do...

title: Another example of how tourism is done badly in India
review: The only well maintained building in the Ashram is the entrance booth where they charge 600 rupees. You could think that with this amount they will preserve some of the buildings inside, but nothing...

title: Yoga and the Beatles
review: South of the center of Rishikesh is the ashram the Beatles called home for a while in the late 60s.  Empty and abandoned for many years, it is little more than ruins.  Buildings of varying architecture, used for different purposes, spring up throughout the rambling hills. Meandering pathways lead from one structure to the next with a central 'boulevard' that bisects the grounds. A cluster of small, 2 story, round structures with pointy roofs were used for living quarters. One is clearly marked "The Beatles Cave." The building intended for the disciples is perhaps the most architecturally interesting, with Moorish arches and peeling paint. The Maharishi's home has a spectacular view of the Ganges.

title: Dilapdated
review: Must've been rocking in it's heydays. It's quite uncared for and run down now. Quite a pity as it's a piece of musical history. Worth a miss unless you wish to experience depression.

title: Very interesting visit!
review: We walked from Laxman Joula bridge to the Ashram which was about 2 km but you could take a rickshaw.Its a nice walk along the riverside and road past shops and ashrams.It is overgrown and deserted but that makes it more fascinating as it seems stuck in a time warp.You can spend quite a while there as there is lots to see.There are individual stone beehive shaped accommodations,also a large pyramid shaped building with lots of rooms and a large hall with paintings and graffiti related to the Beatles.All over the place is very interesting graffiti and you can climb up onto roofs and look at the lovely view.Make sure you see everything as there are places hidden in the woods!

title: Magical
review: Beatles ashram is the calmest most peaceful place you'll ever be.it is breathtakingly beautiful and I went there twice because it is the best place to introspect or see the art cathedral and marvel about the influence of the magical place on the most iconic band of all times

title: Different.
review: This place is very different then what we usually see. Even though it's secluded but they have maintained it enough to retain the interest.

title: Price has gone up!
review: It used to cost 100 rupees to get in. It has now turned into a serious attraction and costs I think about 500 rupees. It is a very magical place to explore and I would not skip it if you are spending time in Rishikesh!

title: Graffiti and  nostalgia
review: A one-km walk along the Ganga, the Mahesh Yogi Ashram, where the Beatles stayed, now lies almost in ruins. Entry of private visitors is not allowed, but you can always get in by being nice to the security guard (which is Rs 100 per person). Of you are a Beatles fan, you can spend an hour or more here, walking through the buildings, and reading and admiring the graffiti that has been written or painted on the walls by fans over the decades. Or just sit on the grass and listen to the songs on your iPod. A very interesting place to rediscover pop culture history.

title: A Magical Mystical Ruin
review: It is located about 1 km from Ram Jhula and about 700 meters from famous Parmarth Ahram behind river Ganga. It became world famous when the Beales came here in 1968 to learn Transcendental Meditation from Maharesh Mahesh Yogi. During their stay they wrote more than 40 songs which featured in  'The White Album" and 'Abbey Road'.In 2003 Uttarakhand forest department took it over after it was abandoned. Now it is run as Nature Park by Rajaji Tiger Reserve. It is in bad shape now but still very popular with tourists. The main attraction here is colorful gaffiti on walls and the place where Beatles stayed and meditated. The entrance fee is Rs,150 for locals and 600 for foreigners. There are steep steps here and no guides or pamphlets to guide you. It is a huge place and it is better to come in group.

title: Took my breath away...
review: Visiting this Ashram has been on my list of things to do for quite some time! It did not disappoint! The property is overgrown - just as it should be. The buildings are a bit run down but have cool graffiti - all appropriate for Beatles fans. I was glad to find decent  washrooms :) Take some time and wander through all of the buildings and dream of the days when the Beatles were there (even though it was not all rainbows and roses!)! Loved it!

title: Rip off price for what it is.
review: Cost 600 rupee to get in. Worth 100 really. Its a bunch of abandoned buildings. The graffiti inside is pretty cool and theres some cool little hobbit sized houses. its quite peaceful but it costs the same as rafting which is so much more fun

title: Dismal upkeep of a historic site
review: Ever since I read that the Beatles Ashram had been reopened to the public I was eager to see it. It is located at the far end of the

title: A bit confusing to find but worth it
review: A pretty cool place, especially when you start to wander the ruins and find loads of rad graffiti on the interior walls ... with a little imagination you could envision the Beatles roaming the property, and maybe even hear the music...

title: great little place
review: Nice food, nice service, nice location... nicely decorated ..loved it...unfortunately only went once since it was always full.

title: Nice place for outing
review: Its a nice heritage need to maintain and monitored for long term, but good to see how Mahershi ji & Beatles been their at early days. A good walk with friends can give you good memories. Its a old architecture and can be good for modern engineers to understand its concept.

title: Real ashram for yogis
review: Wonderful ashram built by shri mahesh yogi for yoga and meditation courses. It is well planned ashram. Feel the energy, vibration.

title: Peace
review: I guess not many people visit this place , its quite unexplored and such a huge place ... Until i saw reviews on trip advisor

title: ONLY GO IF YOUR ARE A BEATLE FAN
review: If you loved the beatles then visit this place.it is being renovated now and they only allow 8 folks a day inside. it is within a nature preserve of tigers, so they are being very careful. lots of grafiitti from old days and you get a better understanding of the beatles time in india with Mahesh Yogi and some songs were written there- i.e sexy sadie, number 9,

title: Charming Ruins of a lost Ashram
review: Recently visited this place along with my friends. Firstly, there are no sign boards that lead you here, gotta keep asking people for directions. The entrance fees is expensive. The ashram is completely in ruins, not being well maintained. In spite of all that, it is worth visiting because of the 84 mini gufaas and the Graffiti tribute to The Beatles :)

title: לא שווה את הכסף
review: Entrance is now 600 instead of 50 rupi per person.

title: What The Beatles got from this  Ashram in 1968
review: About 15 minutes' walk you can reach this Ashram where world

title: Place of ashram where Beatles visited long ago.
review: The Beatles had spent time here (30?) years ago. Buildings not maintained properly. It is in a peaceful and tranquil setting even now, should have been more isolated three decades ago.

title: Seriously overpriced
review: I'm glad we visited as it was a great site and the buildings were interesting. But for 600 INR each we didn't get so much as a map.

title: All you need is money!!
review: First, you need to know if was 50R to visit the place two years ago.  Now, it's 600R per person!!!  In comparison, Taj Mahal cost 750R per person for a wonder of the world!

title: Mystical place in the middle of jungle
review: If you like the Beatles and the legend of them, you will like this place. You can visit the rooms were they stayed or the yoga halls where they meditated. The place could be a little more restored and there's a lack of information panels, but  the visi it's worthyt.

title: You must visit this place if you are in town
review: It is abandoned since years but the cost of entrance is 100 rupees. The ashram is quite big so be prepared to spend at least an hour wondering around the place. After passing the huge hall full of graffities, continue straight and on your right you will see some blocks of buildings. Try to go to the rooftop, as it has an amazing view and some beautiful colorful huts on the top of the buildings.

title: Not to be missed
review: Though the place is run down, with the amount of history connected  to it, the place is a must to visit, away from the city, and in a very natural environment, a visit is a sure thing to do.

title: Must see
review: Away from the hustle and bustle of the city. This place takes you back in time... A beautiful hideaway full of history and beautiful scenery. Still away from the throngs of tourists. Very peaceful. A trip to Rishikesh will be incomplete without visiting here.

title: Ruined ashram
review: It was pretty cool but I don't think it was worth the entrance price of 600 rupees. Nice place in the forest though.

title: Serene beauty.
review: The place lets you be on your own. Take a walk on the nature's path. Though been abandoned for long, it never feels out of touch.

title: Beautiful ruins
review: First it's a huge place so better be prepared for the walk. Second take the right from Rajaji National Park that's where you'll find it. (Nobody will tell you that on Google) Third, its a place of amazing murals so keep your cameras ready.

title: A little gem tucked away in the wilderness
review: The Beatles ashram is one of the most famous spots in Rishi but don't trust your Google maps to guide you till there. It's better known as Swarag Ashram among the locals and I would recommend first time visitors to ask direction to Swarag Ashram and not The Beatles ashram as alot of people wont be aware of the place.

title: Surprisingly beautiful!
review: Nice place to go for a walk and feel like you are being transported back in time. All the buildings lurk out under thick layers of plants, but you can sense the hours and hours of meditation which has been done here.

title: A vast area...shame it is not used
review: Walking around is quite interesting, to see the Maharishi's house before he moved to holland.  the beehive type meditation buildings.  the little houses with meditation cellars.  it is dillapadated though, and now they charge to have a wander round.....shame really.  beautifully positioned.

title: Chaurasi Kutti
review: It was always known as Chuaraasi (84) kutti or Mahesh yogi ashram to all locals. It had been closed for years  due to some legal issues. This place have 84 hut type rooms which have a basement as well on the way to ashram. This place has a yoga hall  with all paintings and posters of Yoga and meditation informational postures and techniques to which  the corridor has dark caves on both sides. Since this place has opened again known as beatles ashram I  don't know how it will be now . There was no access to this place when we visited this place when only a temporary Capsule bridge was built during  Kumbh Mela. It is an amazing place not taken care of by anyone. There was a mute Mauni Baba(saint) who stayed there and had vowed to be silent

title: A must if you're a fan.
review: Visiting the Beatles ashram was one of my "must-do"s of Rishikesh. The ashram is now in ruins, but you can walk up on the rooftops and see the views. I recommend listening to the White Album while you're walking there. Then you can imagine what the ashram was like in 1968.

title: Awesome experience
review: The place does have some eery feeling around it, yet the place is one of its kind. Some of the best moments in Rishikesh spent here. Great place to trek up the hill.

title: Eery but lively
review: It was a bit hard to find and no one was up there. It would be great if there were some signs to indicate something, but it's all completely abandoned and grown over with greenery.

title: do not waste your time looking for this
review: overgrown jungle ,tourist trap, not really anything to be visiting when you have such holy places to see in rishikesh. surely first time novices would seek this out, nothing of substance and a waste of time

title: Beautiful surroundings, little information
review: The Ashram is set in a beautiful relaxing location with lots of green close to the Ganga.  One can easily imagine what it was like to leave in one of the more than 100 small bungalows and enjoy the peaceful atmosphere back when the Ashram was still active.  Some information on the many different buildings would be great. The 'Art Cathedral' is underwhelming.

title: Magic Place!
review: Love this place! Magic and unique ♡ It is definitely worth it to go there... It is going to be around 100 Rps, per person, to get in. Enjoy!

title: A Fun Place to Visit If You Understand
review: A must if you are into the Beatles or lived through that time.  Read the Wikipedia article on it before you go.  If you don't have some background on this place, you will not understand its significance.

title: Side gate. Free entry ��
review: The Beatles Ashram is an amazing and mysterious place. The price is 100. Some of them try make you pay 600. BUT if you continue along the river you will notice some steps on your left which lead up to the Ashram. And you don't have to pay :) great place. Spent a good hour 1/2 inside.

title: I love this place. Don't miss it at any cost.
review: You can't afford to miss this place while you are in Rishikesh.  That's it! The state government has now covered it into a museum.

title: A must if you are a Beatles fan
review: The Ashram is abandoned but you can still visit it paying 100INR to the guy at the main door. It's a good place to take pictures and it is also full of graffitis and paintings related to The Beatles.

title: do not miss
review: this is great place for afternoon. do your sunset ceremony in the old building and enjoy the atmosphire

title: Go!
review: This is a calm and introspective walk in a "park" indeed. It's also like an art galler and history museum. It's so neautiful and fun.

title: Very cool, we played here for hours
review: Would be a nice spot for a picnic... Art hall and uplifting graffiti on Many walls in dorms, domes and buildings. Grab some charcoal and write something inspiring

title: Beautiful place
review: Just go and see.

title: A magic place
review: The jungle is re-conquering the place. The former beauty and magic is still palpable. The architecture is still stunning. You feel like an archeologist. Wonder what it was like when hundreds of beautiful people were milling aroung in the compound with the Beatles and their Guru. Take one of the Sadhus you meet on the way as a guide. About 20 minutes walk downriver, left side, from Ram Jhula bridge. Beautiful sunsets.

title: Serene, Historical.
review: Although known as the Beatles' Ashram, actually a place of meditation established by Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, the founder of the TM movement. This place, the people, who were there and the drama that played out were the genesis for the White Album. Historical significance for the consciousness movement cannot be downplayed.

title: Imagine...you're not the only one
review: I'm on my first trip to India, arrived in Rishikesh and this place was number one on my itinerary . We found it after some asking around, you have to pay the guy at the gate 100 rupees or so to get in; however, TIP...once we entered, we were exploring the area, and behind the prayer huts , we found a fence made of stone . At the end of this stone barricade is a path that goes down to the river, so, had we known, we could have followed the riverbank , you see an old staircase and path by a brick stucture, follow it up about 2 minutes and your "IN".

title: Maharishi and Beatles fans must.  Read up on the history. Stay for sunset.
review: A historic and beautiful abandon Ashram, rich with history, photo and exploration opportunities and peaceful places to hide out and meditate.

title: Awesome place, I'm loving it
review: This place is magic, you see every hype has his time and can wander on the footsteps of the beatles. Good and authentic experience!

title: Faded ruins of a once great place.
review: This is a long walk off the beaten track and is closed to the general public. You can get in if you bribe the guards a few hundred rupees- we did.

title: Sublime atmosphere
review: The ashram has now been turned into a nature preserve by the Forest Service. The paths have been cleared, the gardens are being replanted and the fountains are being restored. Future plans include renovating Maharishi's house as a memorial to his time there with The Beatles and opening up the meditation caves for everyone's use. The atmosphere is sublimely peaceful and a beautiful reminder that it was from here that the knowledge of transcendental meditation and yoga was spread to the whole world. Highly recommend visiting here if you are in Rishikesh.

title: Overrated
review: A rundown place The Beatles once slept at. One of the buildings now has walls covered in a lot of really nice art graffiti, but other than that there's not much to see unless you're a huge Beatles fan.

title: Worth the visit
review: I enjoyed a lot my visit to the Beatles Ashram. The place is left-out, there is a concierge at the door who wouldn't let you in unless you give him money.

title: Hard to find!
review: It's eery to visit this old ashram as the forest is slowly swallowing it up but the architecture of the huts with "egg" shaped roof for meditating is cool. We had several attempts at finding it, my best advice is follow the path along the river in front of parmarth niketan, keep going until you get to the end (along a dirt track and eventually a road of rocks) turn left, about 20-30 metres up at the gate you will need to give the guard about 100rp per person.

title: The place to be
review: We came here by motorcycle, the road is very pleasant and beautiful nature. It's not easy to find the place... We find some strange people into the forest.. . There is a very good energy and peacefull messages all around thé ashram.

title: Peaceful spot in Rishikesh
review: one of my favourite spots - it's wonderfully peaceful even though the once lovely buildings are now in ruins

title: Like Tomb raiding in Cambodia
review: I did not want to spoil my time going to an ashram where went some singers (I dont know so much the Beatles, I mean I know them but I am not fond of them) but my friends were willing to go and I joined them and this was the best part of my trip to India, it was like tomb raiding in Cambodia, in the real jungle

title: Spirit of 60th
review: Well, the main reason of our visit was to see the famous place, where The Beatles stayed for some time and lived there. Now it's totally desolated, and jungles are coming inside more and more.

title: All you need is love...
review: We loved our visit. The Beatles were a part of my youth when they stayed here so it was a sentimental journey for me.  Easy to see why it would have felt like such a spiritual place so many years ago - it still does.

title: Pretty cool
review: I like the ashram, but wish so badly it was kept up and still open, it'd be the best place to study yoga and meditation! I only rate 3 stars because it cost money to get it, which was a surprise to my group, but not too much (100 rupees per person). I think the buildings and huts are cool to explore, but beware, some of the houses have such baud energy. The place is quiet, and I liked that. I did enjoy walking around. Overall I would say it's good, and cool to see, but not super great.

title: The name is 84 Kuti.
review: At the end of swargashram, u will find a way going uphill on the right. There is a big gate which is remain closed by the forest guards. Take their permission n go n see the place. Nice serine place. But beware of wild elephants.

title: Trip down memory lane.
review: The buildings are shells but interesting as the forest is gradually taking over.    You need to give the guy out front 100 rupees to get in.    Inside the shells of the concrete buildings is a lot of graffiti but that didn't really subtract/detract from the experience.

title: Heritage of Yoga/Yogies
review: I went Beatles ashram during my yoga ttc at aym yoga ashram of Mahesh Yogi and Beatle also Belong to Great Yogi Mahesh. It is Amazing place to learn Yoga and great heritage of yogis.

title: Interesting but no information provided
review: I googled the story of the Beatles time in Rishikesh and was glad I did before visiting the site. There is no information once there, just a small sign near the entrance to locked gates. If the person inside feels like it he might let you in for 100rp; I have no idea where the money goes.

title: Calm & Beautiful  !! Need Maintenance :(
review: For those looking for peace place , please do visit this place , for sure you will get closer to nature and The Beatles of course ! It just about 2 Km from Parmarth Niketan Ashram , you have to go off road to get to the place. You can ask any local people for direction. For Entry : As i saw they are charging Foreigners 100 INR and for Local people , the guard seems to little hesitant , you have to be little bit persuasive ,to get into. There You will see around 98 domes like structures which were used by priest for offering prayer to GOD, But as per local person living he said only there are 84 only. BEWARE OF SNAKES, as i found 2 of them while walking.As it is near to Ganga ji you can enjoy view also.there you will plenty Graffiti  on the walks, as some people practicing music mostly foreigners, its nice place to connect to nature.There you will fin any shops for food  or even water, carry before entering the place!! Enjoy the Beatles Magic :)

title: Absolutely love love love this place!
review: Go to the end of the street and keep going, its on the left past the cows and the monkeys! What a gem to stumble upon. Imagining all that was imagined in this place brings me joy. Loved scouting around where the Beatles checked in and checked out. Brilliant!

title: magical place
review: Its like travelling through time. A beautiful architecture, spooky ambiance, if you visit on a rainy day, the abandoned rooms, graffity, the occasional cows poop...well mix it together and you got the basic idea.

title: Cool blast from the past.
review: Maharishi's ashram where the Beatles stayed in 1968 is now a bit overgrown and part of a national park.

title: Beauty in ruins
review: Serene and beautiful...heritage in ruins...though a must see when in Rishikesh...access is not easy and one must take necessary measures to get there.

title: Let It Be!
review: As previous reviews have mentioned, the gates are now closed and guarded by a couple of guys. You have to pay them to get in, we just gave them 100rps for the both of us, we didn't ask for a price, and it seemed to be fine. I wouldn't pay more than 50rps each.

title: Memory lane
review: Its a mystery to find this place... So ill just tell u how

title: Super shanti
review: A must visit for a offbeat traveller. The ashram has a lot of secret and hidden places and some awesome graffiti.

title: good
review: it is one of the least place which was once visited by the greates band of the world, THE BEATLES. So now atleast you gotta visit this place just for their sake atleast. :p

title: Very interesting place!
review: Very strange but very interesting place! If you are in rishikesh, it is worth going there. You have to pay 50 rupies to guard.

title: Fantasy place with special buildings and paintings
review: It worth you spend some time (few hours to half day) to visit. it's a Super fantasy place. That day I went there some guys played music inside the main hall (Saturday or Sunday) A really nice experience. *should pay 50rs for one day multiple entrance

title: Worth to see once.
review: Huge abandoned area with interesting buildings and sculptures. Nice views on Ganga river. It's not worth the 100 rupees you pay to a gatekeeper, though you don't do it often, so it's Okay.

title: awsome
review: historic place where the beatles used to stay in residence with Maharishi Mahesh Yogi… a feel of the sixties community

title: Sort of an adventure!
review: It wasn't open due to some land dispute but we got there anyhow with some local help. Jumped over the gates, nothing like a museum but worth the visit. A little outvof the way.

title: a massive complex to explore and daydream about
review: This was the most surprising visit of our trip to India and one that you will not be disappointed with.  Be sure to get there while it is still unknown!

title: A Trip Back In Time
review: First off, beware of the men at the front gate, they are amazingly creepy and will try to rip you off with prices from 50rs to 150rs. They are not employed by the government to watch the place and are just taking your money and laughing, the place is actually owned by the forestry department. If you want to get in for free just continue on the main road for another 300 meters and head in the back way over the wall. Or if you came via the river just continue on the river side and you will see a pathway up the hill.

title: A place of good memories!
review: It was very nice getting to know the place where the Beatles spend some time in the sixties. Really exciting! the place has a quirky atmosphere and worth a visit, even if it is not so easy to find!

title: Needs more care and info.
review: A quirky overgrown and under-cared for icon that's difficult to find. Bad taste graffiti and no maintenance ruin what could be an immense tourist attraction.

title: Ashram cum Museum
review: A mecca for die hard Beatle fans. This is where the Fab Four stayed, with Maharishi Mahesh Yogi in the 1960s. On the banks of the ganga, near Ram Jhula it is where they learnt the Sitar & Transcendental Meditation. The authorities plan to convert it into a public museum. Work not yet started.

title: a must visit
review: a must place for Beatles Fans.Though in shambles because of Govt apathy,it still gives you an inkling of what it would have been in the days bygone

title: Ghosts of times gone past
review: A hundred rupee entry baksheesh will get you through the gate of this now largely derelict ashram with ghosts of the sixties lingering in the strangest of meditation cells and domes. It must have been remarkable in its day with hundreds of people staying there but now it looks sad and neglected. A must see for fans of the Beatles and anyone interested in the sixties era

title: Derelict yet beautiful
review: I'm so glad I came here. It was like a trip back in time. I wouldn't have been surprised to run into John Lennon. I actually like that it's not been turned into an institutional government run tourist trap museum. One can take a peaceful ramble through the abandoned buildings without being hustled by tour guides.

title: I loved it
review: A great place to hang out.  I filmed a music video here and really really loved it.  Met nice people and visited many times.  Unfortunately the opportunistic individuals that open the gate steal (bakshish) from foreigners and charge an entrance fee even though they will not give you a receipt to prove that it is an entrance fee and claim that the money goes towards the maintenance of the ashram.  Really just a bunch of local thieves with a cushy job.  None of the locals pay to enter and you can just walk up the path and hop the fence for free.  I do not recommend paying as all the money gets paid to a police man that visits once a day to take his portion of the money.  Quite the scam really but a great place to visit even though such con artist sort of piss on John's vision.

title: Best
review: Superb and peaceful place. must visit place. scenic beauty around the place is amazing . to reach here is quite difficult but the peace u find here is beautiful

title: HELP
review: Someone restore this brilliant property. You can totally feel the energy amazing meditation chambers and grounds. A real highlight.

title: Interesting peaceful place.
review: I really enjoyed it here and some of the artwork is great. Just watch out for the vile policeman with a scar who demands money. I see from other posts he has recruited others to take money at the gate. Namaste

title: Spent around 3 hours Exploring
review: It is overwhelming how big this old rundown place is. Just bribe the guard at the gate (100Rps) and explore. Right when you think you saw all of it, you go around a structure and there's twice as much land to explore as you have already.

title: Magical Ruins
review: The Ashram is officially closed down and the property is totally run down, with weeds covering practically everything, trees popping out all over and the buildings falling apart.

title: You can still feel the great atmosphere
review: This place is truly full of magic - I still can´t believe they just let it empty. It´s almost a shame to see how this area falls apart. I love this little stone houses with small terraces in front, some with view over the Ganges and psychadelic artwork inside. And the Beatles Hall is beautiful with all the Graffiti! There is still a very peaceful atmosphere and it´s a great place to hang out for a while. Definitely worth to visit! It´s about a ten minutes walk from Parmarth Niketan, just follow that road.

title: Not really worth it
review: It's ok, it's a run down ruin of a building with graffiti in so,elf the rooms. I didn't see anything to show the Beetles were there. I wouldn't go again.

title: The Beatles Ashram, Rishikesh
review: We had to walk quite a way to see this, but we had come so far to get to Rishikesh!  It has been left to get quite run down which is a shame. There was someone at the gate who charged us 100 rupees each to go in, which we weren't sure was legitimate or not.  The grounds were a little maintained and very peaceful. There were little meditation pods everywhere which were quite 'atmospheric'. You need a bottle of water to walk there and back and spend some time there. Quite an uphill climb to get to the main area, be prepared.  Sue and Pete Morgan, Solihull.

title: Nostalgic must do in Rishikesh
review: If you're in the area you should definitely check this place out, it's worth the trip and the entry cost of 100 rupees.

title: The Beatles Ashram – Nice Tranquil Environment
review: We family and friends went to this place hiking all the way through green woods and the chorus of nature. It was a fine experience. Beatles came here for some yoga and meditation in the late 60s that is why this place is associated with them.  You can enter this place by giving the guard a minimal fee of 100 INRs if I remember.

title: Awesome
review: I was surprised about how HUGE the complex is. It is superb, many graffitis, wild nature claiming back its ground, the old buildings... bring your camera and a flashlight, you won't regret.

title: Beatles Ashram and Cathedral
review: You should do this if you are a fan of the following: (1) Beatles (2) History (3) Ashrams (4) Humanity (5) Solitude (6) Meditation...actually the list is endless. You should do it because you never know when this place might be strictly off limits for public.

title: Baba is funny
review: Before ashram we met with baba who is very old and funny guy. He escorted us and talked about stories. Architecture of area is very interesting and it really inspired me even there is no life inside anymore. It was like that still someone was living there because of some art activities inside.

title: Ashram in jungle
review: We wandered away from the busy streets down a back road ( cows and dogs still) then on to a temple track....didn't see another tourist for an hour ...couldn't go not the ashram as all locked up and getting overgrown but Indian babaji told us about it...followed the creek back down to Ganges and wandered back in to rishikesh...take a hat and water as its a decent walk...

title: Interesting abandoned Asram closely associated with The Beatles
review: We paid the guard at front gates to let us look around and also paid someone to show us the key places and some Beatles history. Its an abandoned ashram now which is a shame but really interesting to mooch around and see the Beatles legacy following their visit to Rishikesh and their transcendental meditation training. Also the Maharishi house had a great view of the Ganges. The ghost temple is only 5mins walk away and if you are lucky you will also see a few elephants.

title: Step back into time!
review: If you like The Beatles, you will love visiting the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi ashram in Rishikesh.  It is, sadly, in a state of extreme disrepair, but all the same it is really fun to walk around and see where John Lennon meditated in #9 (Meditation Pod #9), where Mahesh Yogi lived and taught, etc.  "Beatles Gallery" is filled with wonderful graffiti - it is encouraged! - and lots of opportunties to take photos.

title: Bribe to get in
review: The Beatles Ashram is very difficult to find. We got a foreigner who had lived there for a few months to show us. You usually have to either jump the fence or bribe the guard to let you in (as it's illegal), but we were lucky and didn't have to pay, the guard even gave us free chai! Apparently Elephants often roam through the deserted ashram. It is overgrown but very, very worth while checking out.

title: Run down but well worth a visit.
review: This place is now in ruins but by paying the 100rupee entrance fee  you can get a sense of what it was like in its heyday. I strongly advise hiring a guide (there's usually one hanging around outside and will cost equivalent of US$5). This place was actually a small town with a post office, school and hospital, as well as places for meditation and worship.  The guide will take you to where the Beatles lived, prayed and wrote their seminal White Album. The Marharishee may have gone but you can still sense the aura of peace and tranquillity that was once the hallmark of this place.

title: A Indiana Jones adventure set in the Beatles Ashram
review: Our third visit to the now abandoned Ashram. Every time we go we learn something new. One has to use their imagination to wonder what it must have been like in during the time the Ashram has over 2000 people living there as Yoga community. Today the forest has claimed back the Ashram. While we have yet to see elephants there, the dung is evidence they are around.

title: Great but not officially allowed inside??
review: I would not recommend going alone to this place, especially women, go in 3's at least. If you have accidently entered via the wrong entrance, the guard gets very upset and demands money unless you leave the way you entered-fair enough! A large place, use common sense, its crumbling so be careful where you step or buildings you enter. There were 2 begger type looking men wandering around when we went who had metal bars that they would bang against things and shout at us, think they were trying to be intimidating, just ignore them and they eventually lose interest. Luckily there were quite a few other Westies around that put them off from doing anything too serious. This place was a bit errie, so glad i went though, will never forget it.

title: A must see for all those that loved the Beatles
review: Although its long past its hey day, the Beatles Ashram in Swarg Ashram is a fascinating step back in time to see how they would have lived and meditated and partied during their transformational Indian years. Best go to Hotel Nirvana Palace to arrange a tour.

title: Peaceful and beautiful forested exploration
review: I thoroughly enjoyed the Beatles ashram and highly recommend it to everyone. It is located at the end of the road so you are separate and insulated from the beep beep of the horns and noise, the people selling things, beggars, the cow poop and the chaos of Rishikesh.

title: You don't have to be a Beatles fanatic
review: This abandoned ashram is absolutely being taken back by the jungle. And this is what is so amazing about it. The remaining buildings are amazing, with very cool architecture and some cool and interesting art throughout. It's interesting to walk through and think about the history of the ashram itself, and I'm sure for Beatles fans, that part is especially powerful. Personally, I just loved the energy of the place; it was spooky and gentle at the same time. What I found really special about it, though, is that the jungle is growing back over it and into it. That's what jungles do, and it's beautiful. When I was there, enough of a path was kept mowed to easily get to the structures. It's definitely worth climbing up to some roofs to get stunning views as well!

title: Seeing where the music was made!
review: This ashram is fantastic with all the single meditation caves build from stones and the main hall with the Beatles inscriptions. Loved the grounds, the temple, and the nature of the place. Highly recommend to get a guide so your can learn the 'story" of the Beatles making their music here, and the people who came to see it all and be in sacred space.

title: Beautiful and peaceful!
review: How lucky were we to visit with our friend Sachin that was born there and spent the first 10 yrs of his life there.

title: Beatles Ashram
review: In the mid-1960s, the Beatles became interested in Indian culture,[3] after using drugs in an effort to expand their consciousness[4] and in 1966 Harrison visited India for 6 weeks and took sitar lessons from Ravi Shankar.[5] Alexis "Magic Alex" Mardas, a friend of the Beatles and head of Apple Electronics,[6] had heard a lecture by the Maharishi in Athens, Greece and Harrison's wife, Pattie Boyd, attended a lecture by the Maharishi in London and they encouraged the Beatles to hear the Maharishi speak.[7]

title: A must for no one
review: First negotiate the guard's "Privet Fee", and then be very very disappointed from the ugly ruins...

title: Rishikesh Highlight
review: Definitely set aside half a day to go and see this place. It's beautiful derileict site and plays a unique part in 20th century history

title: one of the best deals in Rishikesh!
review: For 100rs you can walk about the old abandoned TM ashram..woman shouldn't go alone because this place is creepy and an archaeologists dream.....I tagged onto a big group to find the Maharishis dwelling overlooking the Ganges....Beatles original houses were #9! Thru 12 apparently...great art galleries in some buildings and an unbelievable underground catacomb complex of meditation cells......unforgettable!!!

title: It's unique!
review: It's not allowed to enter at the Ashram as I think the government already closed it but we were able to enter cuz you can pay the guard! It's cool and a must see when you're already there!

title: Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds
review: Interesting to see where the Beatles wrote some of their songs.  Great energy and close to the Ganga,

title: falling down and in ruin
review: Head to Parmarth Niketan in Rishikesh and keep going. it is at the end of the road. There are signs everywhere telling you it is a crime to be there, but apparently everybody does. The fence was too high for me to climb, but I took pictures of the boarded up ashram. it is still fun to say you were there.

title: hard to find, worth the search.
review: it took several tries to locate the ashram, but once we did it was absolutely worth it! the entire place is slowly being taken over by the jungle and, according to our guide, occasionally wild elephants wander through.

title: Could not get inside!
review: I really wanted to go, but the main gate was locked and a huge sign outside that says it was closed by the government so if they catch you inside they will charge you 5.000 rupies! No guards and nobody was there... Super sad and a very long way to get there

title: the hippie guidebook..
review: Amazing place if you are fan of Beatles or you love meditation the experience for me was beyond awesome it was so beautiful and i want to thank to "The Beatles Cathedral Gallery" because of them rock n roll feeling their is still alive... and will live forever "Long Live The Beatles Ashram" :)

title: AWESOME!
review: So much to see and do here! I was in awe the entirety of my time wandering the place.

title: It's just so cool being there
review: Had a wonderful time walking around the abandoned ashram while thinking that most of the White Album was written there. Worth a visit.
