A little creepy walking into the different rooms, but I kept telling myself it's a spiritual, not a spooky place. We had to pay 100 rps each, and we know we got totally ripped off since others paid way less, but what could we do with the no trespassing signs? We enjoyed the meditation caves, #9,  and The Beatles Cathedral Gallery nonetheless.

title: The ruins of Maharishi's Ashram visited by the Beatles
review: I must give respect to what this was. The architecture is amazing, the lines and designs inviting and uplifting. The many conical individual meditation huts are so interesting, and inviting to the mind to image what it must have been like. Walking through the gates and up through the entry, my mind was creating images of people there as it may have been, men in dhotis and pajamas, women in sarees, and the serene but enlivening energy of maharishi and his very special students/guests. I wish the government would give more care to the upkeep, but the low fee is also a gift. Ann G.

title: Disappointing, overgrown by jungle and no longer in use
review: I was very excited to visit the Beatles Ashram but upon arrival we found it was overgrown and we had to jump a fence to enter. Some sketchy characters hanging around in this area. It's a real shame because comparatively to the other Ashrams in Rishikesh this is by far the most beautiful architecturally and for it's location, right on a fast flowing, somewhat clean part of the Ganga.

title: memory lane
review: Incredible place to explore.the beatles must have had an awesome time in this special place.the domed chalets with a special meditation area is really unique.

title: Abandoned Ashram
review: Waste of a visit. The Beatles must had an awesome staying there the location is awesome. But the ashram no longer is in use. With zero maintenance the beautiful monument may collapse at any time.

title: a great heritage for beatles lover
review: A perfect place for a gentle hike in a forest, feel the vibes of beatles, their work and the love of fans. The place is also a reminder of fall of the yogi who made it and how he lost favours with then politician. Entry is not allowed, but the watchman can be persuaded with a little "bakshish"

title: Gorgeous but be stealthy!
review: A truly gorgeous ruin but be ninja-like or you may be forced to "donate" to the local police (if you get my drift). Be careful, as leopards and elephants have been spotted on the grounds recently.

title: This is not the Beatles Ashram
review: This is the ashram where the Beatles studied with Maharishi Mahesh Yogi for about 2 months in the late 60s. This was Maharishi's main teaching ashram until summer of 1970.  It's a wonderful place, and the Beatles were there, but it is not the Beatles ashram.

title: Nostalgic
review: Walking into this deserted Ashram, you could feel the energy and buzz of what was once here. The meditation huts, the yoga hall, the gardens... there is peacefulness here, there is heart here, and there is much creativity here. It is sad to think that it is now closed. I hope that someone does re-open this wonderful ashram so we can experience it in it's true glory! Definitely worth a visit, the art work around the place is brilliant!

title: I love everything about it!
review: I'm not even a Beatles fan but going there was amazing. Maybe it's just because I'm slightly obsessed with abandoned buildings but the atmosphere was everything I'd want it to be. I love that you have to bribe the guards 50 rupee to get in and that it's actually illegal that you're there at all. I love the decrepit orb buildings, the artwork on the walls, the fact that it's being taken back by nature and especially the art room (https://www.facebook.com/TheBeatlesCathedralGallery). We came on a quiet day so walking around trying to guess which room they stayed in was eerie and atmospheric. It is a shame that there's nothing being done with this old building which such rich history but at the same time thats what makes it so exciting (and such a cheap attraction!)

title: Loved it
review: Really loved going to see this Ashram. Love TM and the Beatles. Really enjoyed it. Rented a scooter to get there. Beautiful day. Recommend a visit :)

title: HEARTBROKEN
review: I had a group of school kids from abroad & they wanted to go to see the Beatles Ashram, unfortunately the ashram was closed & even after pleading so much to the guard, he did not budge, the kids went back HEARTBROKEN & we were DISAPPOINTED.

title: beatle ashram rishikesh
review: must see place in rishikesh. Ithere is such a great and powerfull energy where you go there, you can visit this old ashram (day or night time), stay for doing yoga or meditation, alone or with friends. It is a weird and magic experience.

title: It is a very beautiful asharam; really loved being there
review: Me and my family went to see this ashram it was only ten minutes away from our hotel; hotel yog vasishth; I never thought after getting there I will like it so much that I will luv to come back I have request to Rishikesh Government they should maintain this ashram; I was bit scared of wild animals but guard in that ashram told me they are seen in evenings only so my fear went away I will recommend must visit place in rishikesh; one should go there during the day because there is Raja ji park behind this ashram so people say wild animals are seen in evenings.

title: Peacefull place
review: Its a very nice place with lot of paintings of beatlez n Maharshi...gud to visit in summers...going dis weekend again

title: Don't miss out!!
review: Don't listen to anyone who says you can't get in... I went today amongst numerous other groups of tourists. You may have to get a bit lucky, and be careful around the front entrance as that's where most people were being denied entry.

title: Its not worth it any more
review: I for one didn’t wanted to believe all the reviews saying that this place hasn’t got the charm that we were looking for but decided to look for it anyways. Interestingly, this place isn’t much on the trip guides and even on the minds of the local people and the ones who we found enough to ask for the directions were kind of unsuccessful in getting us there, so after a whole lot of asking and wandering and then eventually finding a narrow trail amidst the jungle, we reach the gates which is tightly locked and as expected from the reviews, had a guard who would act as if the place is out of reach and would permit us on a little bribe which I found was a little too much and similar to a tout but anyways we managed to pay him some money and then with a frown he let us in and the place was a disappointment with all the jungle swallowing the place and the way this place was left to decay we couldn’t survive for more than half and hour and after taking some pictures, we were out of there as fast as we came.

title: Worth a visit
review: Read a few reviews complaining of entry hassle. Guys this is India ,the guard on the gate is probably very low paid ,unaware of beatles history and just sees rich westerners . I and my wife had no problem whatsoever . or you need to do is give him 100 rupees (about £1.30 } smile Namaste {prayer mudra palms together over heart} and in you go.  The Ashram itself is in ruins but on the afternoon we went very peaceful and good for some quiet meditation and reflection.

title: Beatles ashram!
review: Worth a visit. Follow the path along the ganges until it ends and you come across a wall. Turn left until you reach the old main gates on your right. Next to the gates on the left side there is a little narrow used dirt track up through trees. The path is obvious, so just follow it until you come to a knocked down wall to access the ashram. We ended up having to pay a gentleman 100rs each the sits where the path finishes to show us the way.

title: beatles
review: must visit place.the asharm is  closed  but you still can enter .Once home to the spiritually seeking Beatles,hear the soothing melodies of the Beatles song that were written here drifting in the cool breeze…

title: nice memories, but nothing left
review: Maharishi returned this property to the forest service when the lease expired at the turn of the century. Rishikesh had become a commercial and tourist center, so Maharishi took his ashram further upriver to remote sites in the himalayas, where yogis and pandits continue Maharishi's great legacy.

title: No entry
review: I rate very good just because Im a beatlefan and it was enough for me just to get close and peer through the gate.

title: Charming ruins of a bygone era
review: this place is still flocked by tourists long after it has turned to ruins. it is a little haunting walking through it but still engaging going through the graffiti and messages left behind by travellers from all across the world.

title: Journey towards past
review: Just a few days ago we visited this ashram. Ashram is closed and it is under the Govt Control. We know that we have to pay some money to the gatekeeper to view whole area but he was not there. So we just use the shortcut of climbing over the fence. Previously it was ashram of Maharishi Mahesh Yogi. The beatles came here for meditation. The place was totally lonely when we visited it. The whole ashram is very big and has so many rooms. There are beautiful meditation rooms visible here. I hope that government develop this place in future. Very beautiful surroundings. Must visit for everyone.

title: Fun for a Beatles fan...Watch out for mosquitos
review: A fun place to visit if you're a Beatles fan. It's neat to walk arround and think about there time here. One building has been converted into a rouge place where some have put art up. A few are more interesting than others. But nothing particularly beautiful or insightful.

title: Boring ruins
review: There is nothing great or interesting about this ruin. It is old, not so well maintained and seems ready to collapse. The only thing is its name and that’s all. There are a few pictures inside and that is the only thing that even lends a bit of life to this otherwise boring place. It is worth a miss.

title: open it up
review: the government really needs to do something with this ashram.  visited years ago and it was great to trek through the different meditation huts.  now it's locked and you can't get it.  beautiful area from outside though.

title: Great to visit this pace
review: An amazing experience looking at the photos and the history. Very well mainted but need to focus a bit on cleanliness. Good to know some hidden facts about the legends.

title: dreams
review: the first time i was there in 2001 i had incredible experience, is a place full of good energy, in a beautiful enviroment

title: Serene !
review: had to do a LOT of walking to get here, yet worth it. The Beatles were here at the peak of their career. This ashram is closed but we tipped some locals to show us in. Some of the rooms were really old and creepy. This is the only ashram I've been to among a cluster of many such ashrams, in Rishikesh.

title: Happy Happy Rishikesh
review: An unreal experience, literally felt like a dream, possibly some of the most beautiful architecture I have ever seen, to see the jungle taking it all back is a powerful sight, the people of The Beatles Cathedral Gallery have done epic work, to have seen it in its day must have been breathtaking, the Maharishi and the Beatles have had an incredible impact on human culture, so one can only imagine what it must have been like when they were all there together, one of the great lesser known stories of the world

title: Beatle's Ashram
review: Definitely walk the path of George, Ringo, Paul, & John when in Rishikesh !  Easy to get to, this is possibly the real western birthplace of Yoga. The Beatle's made it ok to meditate, and chant the name of the lord after they visited the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi's Ashram in the 60s

title: CLOSED!
review: After having heard that the Beatles Ashram was closed, we went anyway after  having spoken to some locals who described a back entrance to it.  When we got there though, we were chased by a guard who was very vocal and threatening with a long stick.  He was very adamant that we could not go in.  Apparently it has been reclaimed by the Forestry Commission and entrance is strictly forbidden.  Maybe if you go there in the late afternoon, when the guard has gone home, you could get one of the resident holy men to show you in for a small donation.  But sadly, we had no luck.  It looked pretty awesome from outside though.

title: A mistic place, true magic
review: The only problem is the signs which say that there is no entry... The guard was no very friendly, but there is an opening in the fence somehow if you're really into it (on your own risk).

title: Not really open to public, you pay off a man there to enter
review: The ashram in now in ruins, there have been fires there. It is a very highly charged area, it make you wonder what had happened there for it to come into such poor conditions.

title: A fun an strange place
review: For 50 rupees it's not a bad place to spend an afternoon exploring. There isn't much info, you're literally just wandering around, imagining what everything used to be used for. The Beatles Cathedral located inside was a neat place to enjoy some art. Be aware if you have an overactive imagination, there are some parts that will give you the creeps.

title: The Beatles' Ashram in Rishikesh
review: Hidden in an overgrown jungle, try and get a guide, (they're usually a couple of them waiting for you as you arrive at the entrance) who can explain all the buildings and will help you understand more about how this Ashram ran in it's hayday!  It's more interesting than walking around on your own.  The guy that showed me around was quite short, thin, and had the most incredible piercing blue eyes, with a white Turban, he spoke good English, you'll know him by his eyes - he's excellent!  You need to pay them as you see fit, maybe 300 to 500 rupees...

title: that place is abendond! don't go without a guide!
review: you pay someone in the antrance' but u can't realy understand what is going over there without someone who guide u!

title: Classic visit; nothing that special
review: If The Beatles weren't here, you wouldn't go.  But there were there so we have to go.  The place is technically closed to visitors, though some of the squating Sadhus will let you in for a fee.

title: Worth a break in
review: If you're in to the Beatles and have seen the old footage from their staying there, you shouldn't miss it if you're in Rishikesh. The place is closed, but you can easily crawl over the stone wall 50 metres left of the gate. It's nice to see houses and the atmosphere still lives there.

title: Imagine
review: IMAGINE! that is what i wrote on the wall in one of the run down buildings. Its a pity that the place has been vandalized and the  access is not easy but once you are in its very peaceful and you get transported to a simpler time.

title: worth the visit
review: You will blink or you miss it, as this place is well-hidden and you need to knock on a gate to bribe the "gatekeeper" (we suspect they may have just been squatters) to let you in. You can easily spend hours here wandering through the ruins and imagining the history. The meditation huts are still solid and you can go in and meditate or take some fun pictures. Be sure to hit up the "cathedral hall" and read all of the amazing graffiti. Great energy in there from past visitors. absolutely beautiful!

title: Beatles have been there!!!We have been there!!!
review: Very love this place. So sory that it deserted! but you can visit it for takin some nice pictures!! you need to pay some money for enter or u can climb over fence/

title: Fascinating!!!
review: Loved this place!!! I have been to this deserted ashram many times...

title: Discarded and Overrun.
review: Fascinating place, especially as it's not officially open. But a modest payment to the guard lets you in. Where The Beatles wrote The White Album, copious beehive pod accommodations, and a dilapidated graffiti'd  ashram.

title: The highlight of Rishikesh!
review: Being a Beatles fan, the ashram where The Beatles spent some time in the late 1960s, was an absolute must-see!  It took us a few enquiries before we were on the right path heading towards it - although it was formerly called the ashram of Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, the locals know it as The Beatles ashram so do stop and ask if you're having trouble finding it.  Once we reached the ashram, there was someone there to greet us, I'm not sure what his position was, but it seemed to us he was a caretaker of some sort.  He charged us 150 for the four of us, before opening the gates to this wonderful place.  Bear in mind that this is no longer a working ashram, it closed a while ago. A short walk up a path, you will come across the first of many meditation pods.  We met an artist there who was painting the inside of George Harrison's pod!  Further inside its grounds, you will stumble upon various buildings.  There is no clear explanation of what these buildings were or what purpose some of these rooms served.  We came across a larger building which is being called The Beatles Cathedral Gallery, a street art project. If you're not a Beatles fan, go to see the fascinating meditation pods! You will not be disappointed!

title: Relaxation
review: Very special atmosphere;informality and excellent service. Plenty of time to contemplate and marvellous views.

title: Amazing peace and vibrations
review: Non touristy, nature growing over the ashram, very peaceful and amazing vibrations.  I loved the day here I had.  Om Shanti

title: enjoyed
review: We enjoyed walking around the Ashram for about an hour or so  It is an interesting experience  seeing the abandoned buildings and the new paintings.  A girl from Australia was doing a painting while we were there.  It is a nice park where you can wander around without crowds.

title: Amazing
review: Sooo cool to walk around here. The place that the Beatles wrote their famous and very infuential White Album, a historic moment in music history. The place itself is fascinating, an abandoned ashram, buildings completely overgrown... A perfect place for a horror movie or a Haloween party! The big hall is gorgeous, a hippy walhalla with wall painings and an amazing vibe going on. Definitely check it out!

title: A must!
review: Now this is something you have to visit. It's an abandonded ashram but full of calm and deep energy. Foreigners pay an entrance fee of 600 rupees, and walking around the whole land will take up to 1,5-2 hours. Go in the afternoon when the light is smooth and you can take amazing photos for your Instagram. There's a small cafeteria, but the thing is just to walk around in empty buildings, look at the artwork on the walls and just let Maharishi Mahesh Yogi ashrams energy to sink in. And very near is the tree where Papaji (Mooji's master) used to give satsang when he was in Rishikesh. It is the biggest tree just outside the entrance, ask the staff if you don't find it.

title: Little gem
review: Found by chance , beetles retreat, neglected , but still worth a walk around . Takes about an hour , cost 600 r . Not much information about he place , which is a shame . The photos are good . But only been done later . Been there , which is a possative, but wouldn't go back . Only coz I'm a beetles fan .

title: Beatles Ashram
review: Not quite whats everyone expects. The place is run down and unkept. Spend about 30 minutes visiting the place. Give it a miss, you would not miss much!

title: Peace
review: If you're looking for a respite from the crowd and to find the remains of what Beatles once had and shared , this place is a must visit. The Grafitti on the walls speaks of the times they've had And there is so much peace all around. Look closely and in one of the meditation caves you're likely to find some vagabond painting his/her heart out onto these walls that once stood witness to the art of spirituality and Beatles.

title: A must see if you’re interested in The Beatles or history of popular culture
review: About 45mins walk from LaxmanJhula Bridge is the former ashram of Maharishi Mahesh yogi (founder of Transcendental Meditation “TM” movement). This is where the Beatles famously stayed in the late 60s and wrote a lot of material. Despite its previous place in the limelight the ashram is now a series of ruins and crumbling buildings but it’s still fascinating to wander round, imagine the once buzzing community and admire the well placed graffiti. A must see in Rishikesh, even with the steep 600rs foreigner entrance fee!

title: Return visit after 10 years
review: Disappointed that the buildings have been vandalised.

title: Nice place to relax
review: It is a very calming atmosphere and a quiet getaway. I loved the nature around it and the abandoned places.

title: Brilliant
review: Really enjoyed the peace and beauty of this place, fascinating to walk round all the buildings even though they are left to the wild to take over, a leopard was spotted from one of the buildings. Artwork worth seeing, Cafe on site where you can get refreshments and small snacks, we could of spent the whole day there, would highly recommend

title: Great Place - wonderful relaxing atmosphere
review: I walked there and back. It takes about 40min each way from Laxmanjhula Bridge.
